reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: Supporting the underserved communities in rural Idleb by life-saving aids and COVID-19 preventive masks.

description.narrative: The project endeavors to implement integrated activities between FSL and ERL clusters in the humanitarian field in western rural of Idleb province in Jisr-Ash-Shugur district in Janudiyeh sub-district which is considered as high-needs and underserved areas, for both host community and IDP. This intervention will support 340 IDP households in the camps with live-saving food baskets to enhance their food security which will strengthen their immunity during the outbreak of COVID-19 as well. Also, the project will contribute to develop the household’s livelihood through establishing sewing workshop as CFW activity for 20 women from host community and IDPs to fabricate 149500 masks wherein wearing mask is an essential preventive measure to break the outbreak of COVID-19 pandemic nowadays for specific where the daily statistics from NW Syria about the numbers of people contracted with COVID-19 do not bode well, as the numbers are increasing at an alarming rate that threatens the entire society, which already suffers from poverty and neglection. The proposed location is ranked as high priority for both COVID-19 outbreak and food security coverage for PIN wherein the HNO severity in this location is 4 out of 5. The project includes: I-Distribution of food basket for 340 IDP-households in the camps for eight consecutive rounds where the food basket will cover 100% of the household needs for food in order to achieve their nutrition status and healthy conditions, especially for children, women, pregnant, elderly during winter season and the outbreak of COVID-19 pandemic. The food basket’s weight is 78.3 kg and it will provide the households members with 2100 Kcal/person/day which is equal to 100% per day as per Sphere standards. The FSL cluster recommendation was taken into account in the food basket design and determined food basket distribution modality because the markets in this area consider non-functional. We added 4 boxes of soap to the food basket as a protective measure against COVID 19. II-CFW activity for 20 women form the most vulnerable households from both host community and IDPs by daily 5 working hours and daily wage 5 $ according to the CWG, by establishing sewing workshop for fabricating 149500 fabric re-usable masks according to the Public advisory on the use of fabric facemasks in the context of COVID-19 with low cost , and distributing the produced masks (4 masks for each beneficiary), according to the COVID-19 task force recommendation to, camps and host community. There will be 2 sizes of the produced masks, one suitable for adults 18 and above and other suitable for children 2 to 18 years old. This project will support 37375 beneficiaries affected by the Syrian crisis (8016 men, 8429 women, 10203 boys and 10727 girls divided as the following 11755 HCs, 25480 IDPs and 140 returnees) by promoting their accessibility to the humanitarian assistance significantly. All the people in the target locations and markets will benefit directly/indirectly from the project where the purchasing of the needed materials of both activities will be form the local markets. The project is designed with consideration to the clusters and WHO recommendation on prevention and mitigation measures related to COVID-19 especially during the distribution of support. Also,protection cluster recommendations were taken into consideration, wherein all the population in the targeted locations will benefit from the awareness session of MASRRAT protection team in terms of GBV referral cases, early marriage and child labor risks awareness raising sessions. The target locations: - Janudiyeh village 9055 HCs and 7167 IDPs - Foz-Zuf village 2700HCs and 18313 IDPs with its camps (Az-Zawf 1 (Sham), Az-Zawf 2 (Sadaka Tashi), Az-Zawf 3 (Al Ikhaa), Bayt Soufan, Itshgiz, Mezgileh, Astara, Kafilt Alkhair, Jinan, Katea Jinan, kafr Dlbeh, Al Shaikh Saiah, Al Amal, Kalaat Al Sendian.

owner-org.narrative: United Nations OCHA Financial Tracking Service (UN OCHA FTS)

reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: Integrated emergency livelihood and SNFI support to vulnerable populations affected by COVID-19 and harsh winter conditions in NWS

description.narrative:
With the increasing rise of COVID-19 cases in Northwest Syria and the upcoming harsh winter season as well as persistent violence and a weak economic system, vulnerable people in Dana, Idleb and Atareb subdistricts face significant livelihood challenges and the inability to access critical shelter and non-food items. IDP, host community and returnee populations chronically lack the ability to access livelihood opportunities and the existing manufacturing industries remained strained as a result of the compounding factors. Meanwhile, portions of the population in Dana and Atareb do not have the capacity to work also do not have access to critical household items for the upcoming winter season. This integrated project aims to strengthen the livelihoods of vulnerable people in these sub-districts to produce fabric reusable masks while also supporting people who do not have the ability to work but require urgent SNFI goods for the upcoming winter season.
With the chronic lack of livelihoods and potential impact of COVID-19 as described above, the project aims to: First, scale-up emergency livelihood support focused on mitigating the impact of COVID-19 on the already precarious, pre-existing socio-economic deficits in NWS by providing vocational training and Cash for Work opportunities to 900 individuals in reusable fabric mask production in Dana, Idleb and Atareb subdistricts, and Second, provide business support to 50 new businesses, inactive existing sewing business and women’s groups through business/capital grants and workforce support for mask manufacturers to protect livelihood sources in Dana, Idleb and Atareb subdistricts. As a third and complementary aim in relation to emergency SNFI support, the project will target 2600 households in Atareb and Dana subdistricts that do not have the capacity to work and provide them with cash for winter to purchase SNFI materials to mitigate the impact of the harsh winter season.
This action aims to not only strengthen livelihood opportunities and the local economy but also to produce and distribute 635,000 fabric reusable masks to 158,750 individuals who do not have access to masks. The full suite of activities aims to meet both the acute and long-term needs of the vulnerable communities by providing short-term work opportunities, strengthening businesses, providing cash for winter to purchase SNFI winterization materials to 2600 vulnerable households not capable of working, and distributing critical COVID-19 mitigation materials and sensitization messaging to 158,750 people.
UNDP is the global lead agency in the area of Early Recovery and Livelihoods Restoration with extensive experience in ERL projects, including inside NWS. UNDP will work in partnership with IYD, a national NGO which has experience in both ERL and SNFI projects. On the whole, UNDP will be responsible for overall management of the project and its oversight against programmatic and fiduciary risks through efficient contractual arrangements and administrative support. This will ensure timely implementation of the project, the high quality of activities and the program deliverables. Moreover, UNDP’s early recovery and livelihoods team will provide technical guidance and expertise to ensure the quality and appropriateness of livelihood activities, the sustainability of the business support which will improve the effectiveness of the project and better outcomes for beneficiaries. The added value of IYD is anchored to their experience in both ERL and emergency SNFI activities in Idleb and Aleppo governorates, including previous livelihood support and winterization SNFI projects. The complementary partnership between UNDP and IYD will ensure the success of the project and that the needs of beneficiaries are addressed.

title.narrative: Provision of life-saving in-kind food assistance to the most vulnerable people (COVID-19 patients and health staff) in 5 CCTCs in Northwest Syria.

description.narrative: The project will contribute to Support immediate and critical measures responding to the COVID-19 pandemic through the provision of life-saving humanitarian assistance as in-kind food assistance to the vulnerable people affected by COVID-19 during the treatment period and also health staff in the COVID-19 Community Treatment Centers (CCTCs) which are located in Maaret Tamsrin, Atareb and Daret Azza sub-districts, which were affected by the spread of COVID-19 in NW Syria since September 2020, in additional to the economic deterioration, and insecure situation. The numbers issued by the WHO health cluster upward trend of the injured with COVID-19 as the number of sick reached more than 7500 in NW Syria. During the project's designing and planning phase, SADAD Organization has coordinated and collaborated with ALSERAJ Organization and Based on the coordination with ALSERAJ and FSL Cluster, priority was given to the five CCTCs Atareb ( CCTC-3), Hazano ( CCTC-5), Kelly(CCTC-20), Daret Azza (CCTC-7, CCTC-8) that are located in Maaret Tamsin and Atareb sub-districts, which were classified in terms of priority between high and medium according to the So1 COVID-19 priority locations in the Second Standard Allocation 2020. The CCTC centers in ALSERAJ accommodate 500 patients and 200 health workers per month in all centers. The total estimated beneficiaries number for 9 months (4700 persons) males and females from the host communities and IDPs including ( pregnant and lactating women PLW, the elderly, people with chronic diseases, and the disabled). Sadad will provide patients and health staff in 5 CCTCs with RTERs furthermore, in addition to providing RTERs is necessary to support the same patients and health staff with cooked meals especially for those patients will stay in CCTCs for 15 days without any kind of nutritions resource in Kelly (CCTC-20) and Daret Azza (CCTC-8) Sub-districts, while the others three CCTCs will be supported by ALSERAJ with cooked meals. those contain ( vitamins, nutrients, proteins, carbohydrates, and amino acids..) are important to enhance and support the immune system to resist covide-19 impacts which may lead to death if those not be provided. Project's interventions "life-saving humanitarian assistance'' as in-kind food assistance is including both Ready To Eat Rations and cooked males to COVID-19 patients and health staff during project duration as following: -Distribution of 18,900 RTEs to (13,500 Covid-19 patients and 5,400 for health staff's) within 9 months in 5 CCTCs, where three rations are RTEs during the treatment period (two weeks) for each patient, in addition to three RTEs rations per month for each health staff. The RTEs weighs 5.02 kg and contains 2,100 calories per person per day, enough for one person for 5 days (this is in line with the recommendations of the FSS on RTE ). Each RTERs contains a variety of food items designed to cover all basic nutritional needs for the people in NWS which include (0.4 KG Fava Bean, 0.4 KG Chickpeas Paste, 0.335 L Olive oil, 0.165 KG Canned Tuna, 0.2 KG Zaatar dried, 0.25 KG Halva, 0.25 KG dates, 625 ml canned juice, 2.4 kg bread will be in 5 pouches packed "4 loaves in each pouch packed. -Distribution of 39,060 cooked meals to (27,900 for COVID-19 patients and 11,160 for health staff) during 9 months in 2 CCTCs where one cooked meal per day for each person covers the 2,100 kcal and to be in line with sphere standards and FSL Recommendations as well as maintain food diversity. The centers are pre-equipped with basic cooking from Al-Seeraj. Sadad is committed to secure the primary food items needed for cooking. the centers are divided into three zones, green zone is the last place that sadad is allowed to work and carry out all activities, so Al-Seeraj staff will complete the operations that are in direct contact with patients this is under the indirect supervision of the SADAD team and within the required standards work WHO, FSS standa

title.narrative: Contribute to respond to the most urgent food needs in high-needs and underserved areas in winter 2020-2021

description.narrative: The proposed project targets 7 camps in communities in Dana sub-districts in four communities, most of these camps were established after the last displacement waves between Jan and March 2020, 3 camps are registered in CCCM and the other 4 are not, so GAN will register them as soon as possible, The project target 1102 families with cash for food, the cash intervention is feasible in these camps as they all have access to different main markets in the targeted communities, four rounds of cash for food will be distributed in Jan, Feb Mar and Apr 2021, each round consists of 2 weeks for distribution and 2 weeks for validation and PDM, 50$ will be allocated for each family as recommended by cluster and CWG, GAN conducted a deep coordination with different partners working in the same area as detailed in the coordination section, although the data gained form the FSL cluster indicate to more than 90% respond in Dana but no partner plan to target the same vulnerable and underserved camps, the camps were targeted by GAN bread campaign in Aug and Sep 2020, according to the interviews and assessment, 99% said that the first priority is food, the proposed modality is a cash for food, as it is considered one of the most effective modality since the markets are available near camps, GAN will also train 15 committees in 6 out of 7 targeted camps and equip them with the needed tools for fire extinguishing, FAKs, and other flood tools, and the rest camp will be targeted by point organization as we coordinate with them. GAN developed a detailed awareness plan includes Key messages about COVID-19 for parents, children, coping with stress during COVID-19, dealing with children and adults, PESA, GBV, and PSS, the awareness will be conducted online through WhatsApp Monthly market assessment in terms of availability of the items, prices, and accessibility will be conducted to ensure the local markets are functioning and all beneficiaries have good and equal accessibility to the different goods. GAN will contract with a money transfer agent after assessing the markets and the vendors' capacities in the local markets. where the identified vendors will be responsible for delivering the cash amount to the beneficiaries in the different locations and the payment for the agent will be conducted after finalizing the distribution of each few days which reduces the security risk in delivering the cash in such a complex context.

title.narrative: Emergency food assistance for vulnerable populations in Dana subdistrict.

description.narrative:
With the increasing rise of COVID-19 cases in northwest Syria as well as persistent violence and a weak economic system. Vulnerable people in Dana subdistrict face significant food challenges and the inability to access critical fresh food items. IDP, host community and returnee populations chronically lack the ability to access food, and COVID-19 items. Inflation has taken a serious toll on the prices of basic goods. IYD, therefore, proposes this response. This project will involve the provision of food assistance to 2,000 HHs
IYD, throughout this proposed project, is looking forward to meeting the food needs where many vulnerable families are either receiving inadequate food assistance or not receiving at all thus, IYD will implement the following activities: -Provide 1,000 HHs (2,250 males, 2,750 females, and 250 PWDs) living in Sarmada camps (Kamora Sarmada, Um Near, Bsakala, Salah Aldeen, and Dia'a 9 Kafroma ) with cash for food of $ 50 value on a monthly basis for 6 rounds to buy fresh food at the markets to prevent/reduce the risk of COVID-19 exposure. This activity will complement IYD’s ongoing project with WFP and will target the displaced people in Sarmada clusters who are not covered by WFP project. Building on IYD's current project with SCHF under number 15,000, this project will target the same locations and caseload to improve and sustain access to food for those most in need. In terms of market availability and accessibility, IYD has conducted a marketplace assessment to ensure that target populations are able to access the markets near them. Please see the attached marketplace assessments (vendors and buyers). - Distribute 1,000 ready-to-eat food rations (out of the targeted camps mentioned above) to COVID patients, and people who have had contact with COVID patients and must apply home quarantine. Through this activity, IYD will secure sufficient food items and encourage people who may transmit the infection to apply home quarantine, and thereby, contributing to reduce the spread of COVID-19 in NWS.
Since the allocation paper encourages partners to prepare effective budgets, IYD decided to utilize its own resources to decrease the implementation cost, thus maximize the benefit earned per beneficiary.

United Nations OCHA Financial Tracking Service (UN OCHA FTS)

reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: Enhancing the resilience of vulnerable people in A'zaz to the impacts of COVID-19 shocks through integrated programming

description.narrative: The aim of the proposed project is to deliver immediate support to respond to the impacts of the COVID-19 pandemic in A'zaz.The activities will be complementary to an on-going Covid-19 related project in A'zaz under German Federal Foreign Office (GFFO) funding and is based on OPS project HSYR20-FSCSHLWSH.-165380-1.The project intends to integrate livelihood,food security and wash using a cash based modality.In North-West Syria NWS), the price of basic foods remains extremely volatile and is subject to speculation.Disruptive events, specifically displacement and COVID-19 have harmful and immediate consequences on the households’ economy and may result in reduced consumption and exclusion, requiring the adoption of a framework of priorities and actions that are focused on livelihoods. Proposed intervention has 2components:(1)distribution of cash to internally displaced persons(IDPs) in camps to cover their urgent lifesaving needs 2)Cash for Work(CfW)activities to respond C19 pandemic with a prevention intervention where women are provided with necessary tools/resources to produce fabric masks which will be distributed in schools,camps,facilities.1st component of project aims at covering needs of IDPs in camps in areas of food security and hygiene (multi-sectoral) through cash distribution to support HHs especially in winter as there are less opportunities for livelihood sources due to lack of availability of daily worksamp C19’s impact on market. Primary objective of the project is to ensure that displaced families are assisted and provided with means for a dignified life until they have access to durable solutions.Grant will be provided via a money transfer agent following procedures agreed in SoPsincludes C19 measurements.Value of cash transfers will be $90 per HH for 5months,amount of voucher will be same with current WHH project to avoid tension between organizationamptargeted people.As ongoing project already covered for 3months,suggested project will be covering rest of 5months to be compatible with FSL cluster recommendation.There will be verification process for BNFsactivity will take place in Sijjo Okul (125 HHs), Sijjo Shuhada(154 HHs) and Sijjo Sifira(61 HHs)camps(Total number is 340 HHs).The second component is the production of facemasks through CfW.The benefits of wearing facemasks by the public in general in order to reduce the virus spread in communities is clear especially in locations where high-density gatherings cannot easily be prevented due to living conditions, and which are considered as a high risk area for the rapid spread of infection. Due to the lack of availability of medical masks and the necessity of prioritizing them for healthcare workers, reusable fabric facemasks are recommended. The fabric facemask will have three layers: an inner layer made from a 600 thread per inch (600 TPI) white cotton, a middle layer made from a high-thread-per inch (gt80 TPI) blend of 65% cotton and 35% polyester, an outer layer made from a high-thread-per inch (gt80 TPI) colored polyester. 20 women will be selected to produce the face masks, based on willingness to participate in the activity, tailoring skills (knowledge of use of sewing machines). They will receive a training on how to produce/sew fabric masks. Subsequently, WHH will provide each woman with a sewing machine together with the required materials to be used also for the training duration. Women will be producing fabric masks and will package them according to the instructions given during the training. On a weekly basis, they will be asked to produce approximately 3,000 masks which will be collected by WHH field team and distributed in schools, camps and selected facilities. The quality of the masks produced will be checked by the mask production consultant. He/she will provide regular supervision for the production and will report any challenges to the WHH Project Team. Women will be provided 90USD/month for 8 months. 15 PWD will be supported unconditiona

owner-org.narrative: United Nations OCHA Financial Tracking Service (UN OCHA FTS)

reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: Mitigating COVID-19 outbreak in Northwest Syria by operating 2 CCTCs and ensuring food access for those at risk in camps to both reduce the spread of the virus and the economic's negative effect on their food security (SO1).

description.narrative:
Through the Health and FSL multisector project, Violet aims to implement integrated activities that contribute to lifesaving and NWS’s COVID-19 response by 1) isolation of the suspected/tested positive cases, and 2) provision cooked meals in the existing CCTC in Ariha, but also by alleviating the negative socioeconomic impact of COVID-19 by 3) the provision of cash for food. The project is designed with the following activities:
Health: Violet strives to maintain the existing CCTC capacity in Ariha to isolate the COVID-19 cases to slow down the transmission of the virus. Ultimately, the activities aim to reduce the morbidity and mortality among the community members, as well as to protect the health system from a potential collapse that might be caused by the rapid spread of COVID-19. Therefore, Violet is requesting funds to support the CCTC in Ariha for 11 months as funding from previous sources ends by mid-January 2021. This component will be linked to the COVID-19 response activities to maximize the project impact such as the referral system, provision of PSS, and wellbeing activities to the BNFs in the CCTC, outreach, and hygiene promotion, disinfection of the public places, and masks production and distribution. Further, it's coordinated with Violet's other projects and acts complementary e.g. through referrals.
Food security: Violet seeks to a) provide cooked meals and fresh vegetables and fruits for the patients admitted in Ariha CCTC based on FSL recommendations of at least 2100 Kcal for a person/per day. Moreover, the cooked meals are designed to include nutritious vitamins through fresh vegetables, fruits, pickles, and fresh yogurt to support the quick recovery of isolated cases.
Food security b) Violet plans to respond with lifesaving activities by providing Cash for food (50 USD per HHs) for the most vulnerable and at-risk HHs for 8 rounds. this intervention will also contribute to the COVID-19 response by reducing the negative socio-economic impact due to the COVID-19 outbreak Moreover, the targeted BNFs will also receive soap kits (750 gram/ HH) to improve their access to Hygiene means according to WASH cluster recommendation. the Target locations are the camps surrounding the proposed CCTC, and other CCTC supported by Violet in Idleb to improve the beneficiaries' food consumption of fresh food and vegetables in the COVID-19 pandemic. The cash distribution modality was selected to provide more flexibility for the BNFs to buy their needs, but also to and provide assistance in a dignified way. Prior to cash distribution, Violet will conduct rapid needs assessments to ensure the beneficiaries’ accessibility to functioning markets to avoid the potential harm of cash inputs. Moreover, the cash will be distributed in USD to improve the purchasing power of the targeted HHs without being affected by the devaluation of the local currency
The project was designed complementary between both sectors by the provision of cooked meals and fresh vegetables to the admitted patients in the CCTC in Ariha, which will contribute to improving their immunity and quick recovery. But also through cash for food for the most vulnerable groups inhabiting the camps in the CCTC areas to alleviate the negative socioeconomic impacts due to COVID-19 and also improve their nutrition status when at risk of contracting COVID-19.
During all project phases, Violet will ensure the field teams apply COVID-19 preventive measures according to Violet’s SOPs. This includes applying social distancing, regular sanitization of the CCTC, and wearing face masks. Moreover, Violet ensures the preventive measures during distribution by minimizing the number of cash beneficiaries in each distribution round, carry out the cash distribution in the well-ventilated areas, as well as supplying the distribution points with sufficient hand sanitizers and cleaning materials.

title.narrative: Continuous Support for COVID-19 Community Treatment Centers CCTCs (SDH Centers)

description.narrative: SDH's strategy is to reinforce the continued support of the CCTCs to ensure adequate intervention for providing health services for the new suspected/probable/confirmed cases. Through this call opportunity, SDH is advocating to ensure the continuity of the ongoing intervention funded by SCHF in (CCTC_5 "Al-Seeraj Center in Hazano" amp CCTC_7 "Al-Seeraj Center in Daret Azza") which is ended by 14/11/2020. in addition adding another center (CCTC_3 " Al-Seeraj Center in Atareb") for supporting as high priority location. where the Covid-19 outbreak Disease, is still affecting all the world, including the NWS, there is a high need for humanitarian relief, considering the health system in NWS is still fragile with an urgent need for continuous support and increases the capacity of the response to contain the sharp increase of infected cases. Currently, SHD’s through SCHF support is running two CCTCs located in Hazano amp Daret Ezza communities. Each CCTC will be run by 8 health professional staff (out of 32) to provide medical assessment, monitoring, and supportive therapy for the confirmed COVID-19 infection with mild symptoms and without underlying chronic condition (lung, heart, renal failure, or an immunocompromising condition. The CCTC aims to reduce the burden of the caseload at the overwhelming hospital care services and provide immediate support for the suspected cases referred to the centers including testing and diagnosis while providing supportive therapy for confirmed COVID-19 patients. Moreover, CCTCs will offer separate accommodation and restrict the movement of the suspected/confirmed COVID-19 cases and providing PSS services as well. The CCTCs will be led by the Health Program management as it's already a focal point for continuous coordination with HC amp COVID-19 TF, at field level by already trained amp working healthcare workers and IPC workers and other support staff. These CCTCs are already equipped with all needed equipment to be fully functional, while SDH with this fund opportunity will support the running cost of 3 CCTCs for eight months as the second stage of the COVID-19 response plan which includes 5 fully functional CCTCs in 2021. the modality intervention will depend on the developed COVID-19 Taskforce operational guideline with 50-bed capacity per-center and distributed as follows: 1. observation areas with a capacity of 10 beds defined for highly suspected cases/contact developed symptoms and undergoing laboratory confirmation testing. 2. Isolation and case management areas with a capacity of 40 beds, run by medical staff to provide medical supportive therapy for confirming COVID-19 infection. this proposal aims to cover all the approximately 480,000 population of the Aleppo amp Idlib targeted areas, by improving access to community isolation services for the most vulnerable group as following: (1) children lt18, (2) the elderly, (3) women of reproductive age, (4) IDPs and host communities(5) and people with disabilities, Through our proposed intervention. the estimated direct beneficiaries are 2400 Ind, with the indirect effect of maintaining the health safety of the rest of the targeted populations. this intervention of the SDH organization is well designed to fill the gaps in the current healthcare services in the targeted areas, in coordination with local authorities and Idlib amp Aleppo health directorates. the project has a great advantage as all mentioned CCTCs are already functional, the staff is trained on IPC matter and the supply chain for PPE amp IPC is set with no need for a preparation period for operational processes, contracting, coordination with other partners. as all of these steps have finalized with the full functionality of these CCTCs and with the possibility to extend our current agreement and contracts. Overall the SHD’s through this fund will maintain the current operational cost HR, logistics,s and provision of complementary medicines, consumable medical, PPE/IPC supplies.

reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: Supporting three Community-based COVID19 isolation and treatment centre (CCTC)

description.narrative:
Since the start of the COVID19 pandemic, there have been about 50 million confirmed cases worldwide and more than 1.2 million deaths. These numbers have started to surge in many countries of what is called as a second wave. Meanwhile in Syria, the first case of COVID19 in the northwest was reported in July and it had been increasing slightly before it started to surge in mid of September.
The overall objective of this project is to reduce mortality and morbidity of the affected population, aiming to provide COVID19 primary healthcare service through supporting two existing community-based isolation centres in Maart Tamsrin (CCTC-21) and Salqin (CCTC_24) and establishing one centre in Al-Bab city with an approximate coverage population of 300,000-200,000 inhabitants in each location.
The three community COVID19 centres (CCTCs) have the capacity to provide medical assessment, monitoring, and support therapy for the confirmed cases with mild symptoms. The CCTC aims to reduce the burden of the caseload at the overwhelmed hospital case and facilitate immediate COVID-19 testing through ACU partner meanwhile the CCTC will continue providing supportive therapy for suspected and confirmed cases admitted in Centre. In addition, these CCTCs play the intermediate role of \ a stabilization moderate case without medical complication and facilitate referral case required hospitalization, while received stable cases at recovery stage from the hospital ready to be received at CCTC in order to minimize at caseload at the hospital level. Operationally the CCTC divided into three functioning areas this including: - Observation area defined for highly suspected cases/ contact developed symptoms and undergoing laboratory confirmation test and provision of basic supportive therapy. - Isolation and case management area runs by health workers to provide medical assessment and supportive therapy to confirm COVID-19 infected mild cases. - Recovery area to accommodate the cases under medical supervision until the COVID-19 laboratory test converted to negative. After that, the final assessment and preparation for discharge will be conducted for the cases.
The specific objectives for this project are: - To reduce the spread of the COVID-19 infection in the area of Maart Tamsrin, Salqin and Al-Baba - To manage the suspected COVID-19 patients and provide community-based isolation service for the suspected and the confirmed cases. - To provide medical consultation, oxygen therapy, and drugs for COVID-19 cases.
Main activities: - Procurement and provision of medicines, consumables medical supplies including the personal protective equipment, logistics supplies, cleaning material and stationery, waste management, maintenance, fuel, other supplies essential for the facility to function and provide standard quality health services. - Recruitment of the professional management and medical staff required to manage the CCTCs’ implementation activities (10 medical doctors, 30 nurses, 100+ essential staff support for 3 CCTs) - Establishing one CCTC in Al-Bab including WASH infrastructure and the in-patient wards buildings. while this centre is completed, the staff will be working in a temporary facility rehabbed by WATAN in Al-Bab to be able to start the activities in the first month of the project. - Operate the CCTCs (Maart Masrin, Salqin, AlBab) with full services (case management, isolation for the suspected and confirmed cases, oxygen therapy, supportive treatment) This will be under direct supervision, to ensure the quality of the healthcare services based on WHO standard guidelines and treatment protocols. - Coordinating with the ACU team to facilitate the sample collection in the centre.
Name of the facilities and type of support and HeRMS Code: - Maart Tamsrin CCTC. (CCTC-21) - Salqin CCTC. (CCTC-24) - Al-Baba CCTC. (CCTC-34)

reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: Scaling-up Preparedness and Response for COVID-19 in Northwest Syria through implementing health services to people in need.

description.narrative: The project aims to respond to the most urgent needs identified by the cluster and health directorate, where the targeted intervention is built on the dire need of high severity areas in NWS and will provide life-saving and life-sustaining humanitarian assistance to people in need. The project will apply facility-based approach in providing quality isolation and case management services and will contribute to contain the spread of the COVID-19 pandemic and decrease morbidity and mortality through filling critical and life-saving gaps in response to COVID-19 outbreak. Within the beginning of COVID19 response, SEMA applied to the reserve allocation of SCHF to establish a specialized hospital for case management of moderate and severe cases that could be faced during the pandemic, with complete coordination with Health cluster, COVID19 TF, and case management TWG, thus, Idleb Isolation Hospital (Known as Karlton), a central hospital for COVID19 in NWS, located in Idleb City, which is considered as one of the biggest eight referral facilities for COVID19 in NWS according to Idleb Health Directorate, WHO and COVID19 Taskforce, with the capacity of ( 60 ward beds, 10 ICU beds, 10 Ventilators, Laboratory Dep, X-Ray Dep, 62 employees ) got born out and supported until 15 Jan 2021. SEMA, under the successful partnership with SCHF, aims to complement and build on the impact and learnt lessons of the current project (the dire need to increase the staff number as the nature of this project differs from other health projects and there was a high pressure and over-load on the staff where SEMA responded to that by hiring additional staff from the private fund) by supporting one of the key isolation hospitals in Idleb governorate which witnesses an explosion in the registered suspected and confirmed COVID-19 cases. The Hospital received up to 10 Nov 2020: 254 COVID-19 patients: 106 Ward men, 34 ICU men, 83 Ward women, 7 ICU women, and it has been reported to the COVID19 TF and Idleb health directorate on daily basis. As NWS is entering to the first peak of the epidemic, the hospital currently is considered as a very crucial facility to be supported, as, since 10/10/2020, the percentage of occupations of ICU beds is not lower than 90%, and the general percentage of occupations is around 83% on average. Under this project, SEMA is planning to increase the capacity of the hospital to cope with the increasing needs by increasing the number of staff and supplying the hospital with 10 ICU beds, 10 CPAP devices, and PT device for ICU patients. The project also will raise the capacity of staff in dealing with moderate and severe cases, in addition to activating tele–medicine through 11 ICU specialists from SEMA advisors around the world, who will follow up the cases periodically. The hospital is linked to the referral system of the Idleb Health Directorate, where there is constant coordination between health centers and isolation hospitals. Severe cases, whom could be decided to be in need for isolation hospitals, are accepted according to the vacancy and the case status either in the ward or in the ICU. There are about 45 ambulances distributed over Idleb governorate and its countryside where 10 of these ambulances are equipped with mobile ventilators. The Health Directorate coordinates admissions among the health facilities, CCTGs and isolation hospitals through WhatsApp groups. When the patient (tested positive) arrives at the hospital by ambulance s/he enters the triage room and the physician examines and evaluates him and he requests x-rays and medical analysis, and if the case is suspected, a special triage form and an admission file are filled out, vital signs and analysis are recorded in the file, medicine is prescribed, then the patient's condition is monitored by physicians and nurses until he is discharged from the hospital.

reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: Respond to COVID-19 Pandemic Through Supporting CCTCs

description.narrative:
The project aims to support 5 COVID Community Treatment Centers (CCTCs) for 8 months, which are the most effective ones out of the 13 centers currently functional and operated by UOSSM. These centers provide services for treating mild and moderate cases of COVID-19, as they are considered the largest percentage of confirmed cases, ensuring that only the severe cases in which the morbidity is high reach out to the case management hospitals and ICU. The intervention in the project aims to address the gap in response to the COVID-19 pandemic in northwestern Syria (northwest rural Aleppo and Idlib) by supporting CCTCs, where surveys will be conducted for all suspected cases of COVID-19 that meet the criteria for the swab (PCR) to be taken and If it confirmed, mild and moderate cases will be admitted, quarantined and treated ( except that are asymptomatic with suitable home circumstances for quarantines ), thus containing the spread of the COVID-19 pandemic and reducing morbidity and mortality rates. The project also includes educating patients and teaching them how to use personal protective equipment and training them in practice. These centers are located in Kafr Karmin, Atma, Sarmada, Armanaz, and Dana, which are in the hot area of OCHA allocation and have a population of (998861 for Dana District), 74430 for Armanaz District, and 176282 for Atarep District). The WHO indicated on August 14, 2020, that studies are varied about Covid morbidity, In any case, global studies indicate that approximately 20 - 40% of positive cases asymptomatic while, 60 - 80% symptomatic ( 5% of them needs ICU, 15% hospitalization, and 80% CCTCs ). According to the statistics of the previous 5 CCTCs, length of stay (Los), and the capacity, the number of beneficiaries was calculated at 333 per month for each center (1665 for 5 CCTC centers)The center will be as WHO/HC model that include 4 areas: 1- Triage (first acceptance area in which application filled and IPC s provided) 2- Screening and physical evaluation in which admission, referral or home quarantine decision will take 3- Observation and isolation in which admitted cases 4- Recovery when patient prepared to discharge.
Codes and Names of the Targeted CCTCs: Name Code Dana CCTC CCTC_4 Atma CCTC CCTC_28 Kafr Karmin CCTC CCTC_30 Armanaz CCTC_02 [Sarmada CCTC_25 Facility name Governorate District Sub-district Location Location code Latitude Longitude Atma - COVID 19 Idleb Harim Dana Atma C4130 36.30862 36.6889 Kafr Karmin (co) -COVID 19 Aleppo Jebel Saman Atareb Kafr Karmin (co) C1035 36.16145 36.78847 Armanaz - COVID 19 Idleb Harim Armanaz Armanaz C4176 36.0833 36.50229 Dana - COVID 19 Idleb Harim Dana Dana (Dana) C4126 36.21196 36.77046 Sarmada - COVID 19 Idleb Harim Dana Sarmada C4121 36.18423 3 6.72314

reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: Provide seasonal and supplementary NFI assistance and CCCM services for the most vulnerable in North of Syria

description.narrative: Takaful through this project aims to meet the basic needs of heating items to the most vulnerable in Idleb and Aleppo camps by providing them with seasonal NFIs through restricted e-vouchers for 3 months in addition to establish fire points and raising awareness about the fire hazards, prevention and mitigation procedures in the same camps . The project will target 3233 HHs 16165 individuals (3718 men 3880 women 4849 boys 3718 girls) as follow: Azaz 1409 HHs (Alrayan) Camp Dana 1185 HHs (Al Salam, Al-Ahmad, Abnaa alziara, Al Wdahee, Aldarraj, Maarrat Dibsah) Camps Atareb 639 HHs (Al Raay, Batebo, Ziytan , Al Tal) Camps Interventions will target the same beneficiaries as follow: NFI Distributing e-voucher with $150 value to redeem it with heating items for 3 months, where monthly $50 will be loaded. Firstly, Takaful will conduct meetings with local actors to ensure their participation in the project. The fuel vendors will be selected according to certain criteria. As we already work with e-voucher vendors in some of the targeted locations in another project funded by HF , that will support our efficient and fast implementation for this project. Beneficiaries will be selected among the most vulnerable (male-female). The voucher distribution will be on pre-identified dates and in safe points with easy access. Instead of physical training, as a response to Covid, an explanatory video will be prepared and shared with benes, includes how to redeem vouchers, vendors' names and addresses, WtsApp number for complaints, in addition to banners describes the redemption process and vendors’ information. After ensuring that the beneficiaries have redeemed their vouchers from the vendors, the value of the items will be paid to the vendors. For HHs who face difficulties in reaching the markets, we will deliver their vouchers to their locations, and giving them the chance to choose kinds of provided items they prefer and then delivering it to their locations. We chose the voucher modality as it is easier to use and follow up, and gives the beneficiaries the choice to buy what they want from multiple vendors to avoid the risks of fuel storage, where the beneficiaries will visit the selected vendors shops and choose the heating items they need. CCCM We will establish fire response committee (males and females) in the targeted camps in order to mitigate the risks of occurring fire, in addition to best response to fire when it occur. We will provide capacity development to committees and camp management staff to response to fire through the training on using of fire response items. In addition, Takaful team will prepare an awareness video and e-brochures explaining the prevention advices to avoid fire, and how to use fire response items in case fire occurred to raise the awareness of camp residents. In coordination with camps’ management and fire response committees in targeted camps, fire points will be putted in suitable locations, where each 140 tents will be provided with fire point includes fire response items The trained committees will transfer the training to the camps’ residents. We will insist on prevention procedures for COVID-19 before, during and after the distribution, including distancing, procedures of sterilization staff and beneficiaries, awareness posters, crowds management, sterilizing DPs according to WASH amp health cluster’s recommendations in addition to allocate an employee to monitor and make sure that all COVID-19 prevention procedures were applied. We will coordinate with CCCM and NFI clusters and other organizations to avoid any duplication. The project will ensure equal access for both genders with priority for women, children headed household, PwD, sick and elderly in addition the project staff female and male members trained on the protection and gander equality

reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: Scale up of Winterization Response in NW Syria 2020-2021

description.narrative:
**Mercy-USA for Aid and Development in this project will support internally displaced persons (IDPs) and host community in Afrin, Jandairis, and Dana sub-districts with winterization support in the form of in-kind, eco-friendly biofuel, and stove kits
Total number of beneficiaries who will be targeted 3567 HH - 17880 individuals (Men 3592- Women 3929 Boys 4822- Girls 5537) by using in-kind modality for implementation for the most vulnerable households. Mercy-USA will target each household with in-kind 750 kg of olive pit fuel (250 kg per month) throughout the winter months (December 2020, January 2021 and February 2021). The initial fuel distribution will occur along with the stoves’ distribution or shortly after distributing the stoves to 100% of the targeted households to ensure all beneficiaries have the appropriate stoves to use olive-pit fuel
The Shelter NFI cluster recommendations at minimum 750kg/ HH/ 3 months, however, based on many PDM conducted by Mercy-USA after each winterization project since 2015. Always the quantity is not enough for beneficiaries given the fact of harsh winter seasons in the last few years in NW Syria, so as lesson learned, we increased the distributed quantity per HH to be total (750 kg/ HH/ 3months)
Mercy-USA will distribute olive-pit fuel to the beneficiaries directly on monthly allotments based on monthly distribution plan by specifying dates for each location.
The implementation plan is the same in Afrin and Jandairis will be the same, however, Considering the beneficiaries are identified and verified in Jandairis, it is assumed distribution can start earlier in Jandairis communities
**Mercy-USA will distribute masks and soap along with stoves and fuel to the same beneficiaries to ensure protective measures against COVID-19 are in place without doing harm. each HH will receive five mask and 700 gram of soap on monthly basis. Soap will be donated by IRC to Mercy-USA in order to be distributed along with fuel as in integrated response and complementarity approach while masks will be purchased by Mercy-USA
**Accountability to Affected population (AAP) will be given high priority in this project by communications and sharing information with beneficiaries during all project phases, as well as using complaints and feedback mechanism which is accessible to all beneficiaries especially the most vulnerable such as persons with disabilities, the elderly, women and girls, thus taking corrective actions based on need.
** Furthermore, MEAL plan will be for all project stages such as verification of vulnerability assessment, distribution monitoring, PDM, with using different MEAL tools.
**Reporting will be on timely basis according to the priority, ex, narrative report will be interim and final, while other reports will be on a weekly basis.

title.narrative: Provision of life-saving winterization support to the IDPs in Al harakat and Aljabal camps in Ghandorah and Jarablus.

description.narrative: Project Summary: Through this project, Binaa organization seeks to provide support and to response to 2,199 conflict affected IDP HHs (11,174 individuals) (2,305 women, 1,976 men, 3,183 girls and 3,710 boys) in both Aljabl and Haraqat camps in Jarablus and Gandoura villages throughout providing stoves, and sufficient heating fuel for 3 months as per 4 liters for the day. through this support Binaa will ensures the integration of the food security response and the winter needs response, while Binaa is already providing bread for the all the families in these camps on daily basis since Oct 2020 and that will extend to March 2020 under one of SCHF ongoing project. Each beneficiary household will receive stove and diesel for 3 months based on 4 liter per day, Total 360 liter, the diesel will be packed in jerrycans, (Heaters, Diesel, and jerrycans specifications are attached to the proposal (Attachment T 01) Binaa will distribute 3 patches of fuel, the first one (120 liters) will be in December 2020 and it will be conjugated with stoves distribution, the second one (120 liters) will be in January 2021, and third one (120 liters) will be in February 2021, according to the time plan of the project (Attachment A 01). The distribution will be in kind at the main distribution points and the quality of the diesel will be checked before distribution, however, the fuel kits will be delivered to the elderly (over 60 years old), people with special needs, and the people who are unable to reach the distribution point for any reason directly to their house (door to door) that will decrease the risk of COVID 19 on the elderly people. Verification visits (100% of beneficiaries) will be conducted after each distribution to ensure that the beneficiaries are still available to receive the next batch and ensure that they are using the heaters and fuel. Binaa will follow the SNFI recommended procedures for the distributing of NFIs during COVID-19 in addition to follow Binaa guidance in this regard (Attachment A 02), the following are some of these procedures: Preventive measures will be taken to ensure social separation and availability of enough area, that will reduce the risk of spreading of COVID-19, the plan for the distribution point which will be equipped with cones and plastic chains to regulate the entry and exit process is attached to the proposal (Attachment T 03). The team will share the distribution plan with the camp management and will inform the beneficiaries a day before the distribution process, and the beneficiaries will be divided into groups to ensure less gathering of the people, however, cards will be given to each beneficiary with the time and date of receipt. Beneficiaries will be advised to leave the distribution location moment they receive assistance, they will not pass through the distribution point more than once. Binaa will distribute masks to the beneficiaries HHs (5 for each one) as per SNFI guidance for COVID 19, that will be done with each fuel distribution. Awareness sessions will come along with verification/distribution activities , these awareness sessions will focus on 2 main topics, 1- the best procedures for dealing with fires, 2- COVID-19 awareness (following proper hygiene practices, Covid-19 spread, pandemic symptoms, and the ways to deal with it in case of getting the disease), beneficiaries will be provided with the numbers of emergency/actors that can deal with the cases, (the list is attached to the proposal (Attachment A 03)).

title.narrative: Enhance the resilience of the affected communities against COVID-19 in the northwest of Syria

description.narrative: MWL has designed the project based on people-centered approach, in line with the most recent needs assessments, clusters’ inputs. MWL will implement integrated project in protection (CP-GBV-GP), ERL, and WASH sectors, covers 2sub-districts: AlBab and Dana which have been prioritized in SO1 COVID-19 in (Sarmada, Tal Elkaramej, Dana, Atma)in Dana,(Bazagha, Al-Bab) in Albab sub-district. Project serve (91175) of the most vulnerable (M:26441, W:24619, B:20967, G:19148, PWD: 466) through: *Protection intervention, MWL will expand protection services through the 2 MWL existing community centers in Dana and Al-Bab, and 6 mobile teams (Each one consists of 4 members: 1 team leader and 3 team workers(CP, GBV, GP), for 45,250 "M:6400 -W:22550 -B:7900 -G:8400" affected by crisis and COVID-19, with concentrating on infected, relatives of those in quarantine and isolation, those exiting quarantine, in coordination with Health Cluster/MHPSS helpline, COVID-19 TF, and partners health NGOs - Group-based PSS/Strengthening of community aiming at changing stereotype ampstigma, maintaining confidentiality towards affected Corona patients amp their relatives. - Provision of information, advice and "PFA" for groups with specific needs like elderly, PWDs - Provide prevention and awareness-raising activities on GBV amp CP concerns, risks associated with COVID-19 and key messages for health actors and in quarantine centers on referrals and service provision. - Provision 2000 dignity kits for WampG in quarantine. - Conduct identification and referrals especially for cases with health care needs. - Deliver CM services for vulnreableampat-risk children, with developing individual care plans. - Deliver IPA services for most vulnerable especially those affected by pandemic - Provision of 3000 child PSS kits for children in quarantine centers for fostering a child-friendly environment. - Support existing CPNs to prevent and respond to protection threats related to COVI9. *ERL intervention, it will improve livelihood support for 240 of most vulnerable and pandemic/crisisaffected women and their families in Dana and Al-Bab, delivering CFW interventions designed to increase local production of fabric re-usable masks by: -Conduct training for women participants in CFW activity for 5 days on masks production. -Produce and distribute 300000 fabric re-usable masks (per WHO standards) within 3 cycles of CFW. The selection criteria for CFW beneficiaries will give priority for women referred by humanitarian actors (more details in log-frame) Distribution of produced masks will be through protection channels, targeting most vulnerable groups: elderly, PWDs, newly IDPs, female-headed households, women and children in the high infections areas. *WASH intervention: will target 29370(M:6197, F:6940, B:7618, G:8615) including PWD and elderlies in camps and communities that recorded COVID-19 cases with hygiene kits to avoid outbreak of COVID-19 in AL Bab amp Dana sub-districts, and deliver hygiene promotion key messages based on WHO recommendations, door to door awareness sessions, and awareness-raising on personal hygiene and protection measures for 30370 (M: 6447, F:7190, B:7868, G:8865) including PWD and elderlies. MWL strictly coordinated with NGOs have health ,GBV, other services to exchange referrals and specialist services. MWL will deliver training amp technical support to health teams amp Quarantine centers staff of SEMA, UOSSOM, SAMS, IDA, Al-Ameen in Dana and Al-Bab, on protection principles amp mainstreaming, identification and referrals related to CP, GBV, GP. MWL will refer individuals and families who need medical care and GBV survivors who need CM to health amp GBV partners, and receive protection cases referrals. MWL will benefit from its protection projects in Dana, and Al-Bab to get support amp referral where a good access in Idleb and Aleppo. MWL developed the project with a strong risk management strategy, in line with the allocation strategy

title.narrative: Providing Protection and WASH services to people affected by COVID-19 in NW Syria

description.narrative: This project aims to provide 213,242 BNFs with WASH and Protection services to affected people with a high focus on COVID-19 and quarantine centers in Al-Bab, Daret Azza, Atareb, sub-districts to support the resilience and access to services considering the full and strict application of COVID-19 prevention precautions according to the recommendations of WHO. The project's interventions have put a strong emphasis on providing emergency WASH and protection services that can meet the different needs of men, women, boys, and girls with full consideration of the specific needs of the most vulnerable groups women, children, elderly, and people with a disability with full application of COVID-19 prevention measures to support the affected communities by delivering aid through experienced staff who already implemented similar projects in the same locations and gained the acceptance as follow: 8 quarantine and isolation centers will be served by both WASH and Protection integrated services as a response to COVID-19 and provide a safe environment to affected people as follow: Support quarantined people with hygiene kits Provision of information and PFA to quarantined people including elderly, PWDs, and individuals at risk Provide group-based PSS to quarantined people. Strengthening of community support for quarantine and isolation centers through establishing community committees in each location Provide awareness-raising sessions for individuals in quarantine in protection, CP, and GBV. Identification and referrals for specific needs and concerns along with receiving referrals from C19 helplines. Case management for CP and GBV affected people with high risk and concerns in quarantine centers. Distribution of PSS kits to children, and dignity kits to girls and women inside quarantine centers. Build the capacity of the quarantine center’s health staff on protection principles, identification and referrals, and GBV key messages. The intervention will continue targeting the affected communities with both WASH and Protection services through, provision of diesel fuel, engine oil, and spare parts (diesel filters, oil filters, air filters for generator), in addition to the provision of Sodium Hypochlorite, or liquid chlorine, which qualified staff will add it to the water supply via the chlorine dosing pumps for operating and maintenance of the 16 water stations belong to Al-Bab water system for two months until completion of connecting the stations to the electrical network. On the other hand, the community-based protection will be enhanced through the establishment of community committees to deliver prevention services in line with COVID-19 prevention measures Repair existing WASH facilities including replacement of malfunctioned handwashing basins, taps, showers, toilet seats. Provision of safe and adequate water Installation of handwashing units Provision of desludging or connect to existing wastewater collection if needed. Provision of solid waste collection, separation, and disposal services with attention to a sanitary disposal system Support WASH facilities with cleaning materials and tools Support frontline workers with PPE kits Strengthening of community support for quarantine center through establishing community committees in each location Provision of PFA, PSS, and Awareness-raising sessions to affected communities through emphasizing community-based protection. The mentioned services will be delivered through 4 protection mobile teams (1 in Dana, 1 Daret Azza, 1 Atareb, 1 Al-Bab) and 2 WASH site engineers and 2 field officers, with close coordination with COVID-19 TF, MHPSS WG, and Health cluster and directorate and the governorship of Gaziantep, along with the flexibility to shift to the online protection services provider.

title.narrative: Integrated WASH and ERL response to the negative effects of the COVID 19 pandemic on the affected communities in NWS

description.narrative: Our response will focus mainly on two sectors, WASH and ERL where we seek through this integrated response to reduce the risks of the Covid 19 pandemic among the already affected people. Our strategy depends on innovative intervention to confront the economic and social impacts of Covid 19 and limit its spread and its effects on the vulnerable people, where the water, sanitation and hygiene package is designed to limit the spread of the Covid 19 and change the wrong and unhealthy hygienic practices and provide the needed personal items that will protect people and enhance their personal hygiene, while the ERL packages will work to help vulnerable people to overcome the negative economic and social results left by the spread of the Covid 19 beside the Syrian crisis through the provision of short-term labour opportunities to skilled and unskilled workers supporting 180 HHs Who will mainly responsible for producing around 155520 reusable masks through the cash for work that will be implemented. Silk Road will establish (3 ) workshops equipped with the necessary equipment to produce these masks as well as some women will participate from their homes if any (Women have a Sewing machine), while the organization will secure all other materials needed for the production of the masks. The workshops will be in Batenta, Maaret Elekhwan and Kafr Karmin and the main beneficiaries will be selected from these locations. Silk Road will seek to use existing workshops if any and in case it is not possible then we will go to establish new workshops knowing that this will not cost a lot and will not take a long time as well. The produced masks beside soap that will be secured by the organization will be packed in boxes or bags and this package will be distributed to the beneficiaries in two ways (The first by the hygiene promoters when they visit the family and the second by the head of the family who can come to the workshop to pick up the package). The sewing machines will be handed over to the number of families after the project ends ( Kind of sustainability of the project under an agreement with women, standers and criteria for selection). Silk Road will select the most vulnerable women (Families with no income generation) in each targeted community and we will prioritize IDPs, women ith disabilities, and women-headed household also we will take into our consideration the size of the family and persons he has the ability to work if any. Silk Road will study each case before producing the final list and we will transparently work with the community. Also, once we select the women, we will sign an agreement with them to ensure the rights of each party. The approach that we will follow in implementing WASH intervention to achieve the desired goals will be based on providing the needed safe drinking water to people as well as support and manage waste collection systems to maintain a safe and clean environment in addition to distributing hygiene personal supplies (Soap +Masks (4 per person) that helps reduce the spread of the Covid 19 epidemic, in addition to re-usable face masks that we will provide through early recovery activities that we will support. These activities will be accompanied by awareness-raising activities that will be provided by the hygiene promoters who will be assigned in each targeted communities(Two in each one). During this period of support (Operation of the water systems), a cost recovery system will be established to ensure continuous cash flow required for running the systems during and after the project (Only the first two months of the project will be supported 100% while the others will be partly supported), this will involve a study on a suitable tariff rate that takes into account the dwindling financial capacity of the benefiting population and will be based on focus group discussions with a representative group of the community including members of local councils of targeted communities.

title.narrative: Emergency WASH/COVID-19 assistance for the most vulnerable people living in Jarablus District

description.narrative:
In recognition of the risks and urgent needs associated with outbreak of COVID-19 and increasing IDP population in NW Syria, CARE will leverage its technical leadership, operational experience, financial resources to provide coordinated assistance to conflict-affected communities, especially the newly displaced one living in Jarablus district. CARE aims to implement WASH activities to mitigate the risk of COVID-19, including increasing hygiene promotion, mass COVID-19 messaging at camps level, providing an increased amount of required clean water to facilitate handwashing practices. CARE will increase the amount of water to 35 L/person/day, reaching 15,250 beneficiaries. Additionally, CARE will work to encourage and facilitate this practice for targeted people living in camps and in communities and will distribute cleaning/disinfecting materials and soap through awareness-raising and behavior change activities.
CARE proposes to support 3,050 HHs living in Old and New Zoghara Camps located in Jarablus with WASH services in this project. The camps were built by AFAD in 2017 to host IDPs fleeing conflict areas in NW Syria. Through the funds from the first standard allocation 2020, CARE extended the new camp to host 1,200 HHs in addition to the 1,850 HHs living in the old camp and improved lifesaving conditions by replacing damaged tents with new ones, insulating tents and implementing graveling and ground site preparation in addition to securing safe access to WASH facilities in consideration of COVID-19 precaution measures.
The camps are among locations with high reported cases of COVID-19. 104 cases have been recorded in the camp. CARE in coordination with the stakeholders has completed the establishment and set up process of a quarantine zone at new Zoghra camp. The quarantine zone consists of 50 tents facilitated with NFIs. Public WASH facilities have been prepared with equipment to serve the quarantine area. CARE has ensured that the quarantine zone is isolated from the camp’s remaining sectors by selecting the appropriate location and having it separated with a surrounding fence. Local authorities hold responsibility of providing necessary medical equipment and staff.
Access to water is essential for effective handwashing, which is one of the most important measures to prevent COVID-19 infection. CARE will work on securing safe access to adequate drinking water by operating water stations, providing the camp with water (35 L/P/D), provide water storage tanks for IDPs and to reduce crowdedness around current distribution points. CARE will conduct full water quality analyses on water sources in advance. Trucked water will be chlorinated and FRC levels will be checked daily throughout the entire supply chain.
Essential emergency services such as desludging, latrines, soap provision will be provided. To reduce overcrowding, improve hygiene behaviors and increase access to handwashing facilities, CARE will install new shared family latrines where Sphere standards are not met (one toilet for every 20 people), installing door locks for safety and privacy and providing appropriate lighting. CARE will also undertake minor repairs to existing latrines including quick fixes of handwashing facilities in particular and cleaning of latrines, including disinfecting communally used surfaces to mitigate COVID-19 infection risk.
For the prevention and control of infections, CARE will apply intensive hygiene promotion sessions. CARE’s hygiene volunteers will be in charge of disinfection measures to mitigate the spread of COVID-19 in camps. Disinfection kits including soap and PPE will be distributed along with one-off hygiene kits to all families in the camp. Volunteers will be assigned to sterilizing latrines, water distribution points and WASH equipment such as water tankers using the provided cleaning materials and disinfectant liquid.

reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: Integrated Rapid Response to WASH Gaps to Prevent Suppress and Interrupt Transmission of COVID-19 in Idleb City.

description.narrative:
The project addresses the spread of the COVID-19 epidemic in densely populated areas of Idleb sub-district ranked as high in severity of WASH needs. The proposed action will contain the spread of the COVID-19 epidemic and decrease morbidity and mortality through providing rapid, life-saving Water Sanitation and Hygiene (WASH) services to vulnerable, underserved and at risk communities.
Planned activities respond directly to gaps in WASH service provision which have been jointly identified with the WASH cluster. These are made further more critical by the high risk of COVID-19 in Idleb sub-district, specifically in the dense, over-populated areas targeted in Idleb City. Informed by Big Hearts operational experience with WASH service provision in Idleb City, complementary to our ongoing interventions and designed in full coordination with other actors, the action will scale up water provision and enable improved COVID-19 prevention and response.
The project will benefit a total of 60,500 conflict affected people living in the Al Gazl station and Street 30 borehole catchment areas of Idleb City. Of these, 28,030 direct beneficiaries are Internally Displaced Persons (IDPs), 30,854 are female and 33,274 are children.
The action will prevent, suppress and interrupt transmission of COVID-19 through increasing and safeguarding access to safe water in areas with identified gaps. Provision of operational and maintenance support to the Street 30 borehole will begin in Dec 2020, meeting the gap in service provision since Big Hearts previous SCHF-funded support to Street 30 ended in Sept 2020. Complementing ongoing SDC-funded assistance, the project will maintain vital operational and maintenance support to the Al Gazl station from February 2021 when SDC funding will close. In coordination with SEMA, WASH services will be improved in two, existing COVID-19 quarantine centers located in the Al Gazl catchment area through connecting these to the primary water network.
In addition to ensuring access to safe water and informed by Big Hearts participation in established COVID-19 coordination structures, Risk Communication and Community Education (RCCE) activities will be delivered across targeted communities in close coordination with UNDR and Violet. This will include highly targeted distribution of hygiene and sanitation materials (soap, detergents and cloth masks) directly benefitting 17,500 people most vulnerable to the pandemic. The targeting strategy for this component with be informed by close coordination with the COVID-19 Task Force and other members to identify areas with higher C-19 case numbers and areas with dense / inadequate shelter. Vulnerability targeting will then identify households most at risk amp least able to practice positive prevention practices.
A people-centered approach lies at the heart of the intervention. Programme design reflects the needs, priorities and preferences of beneficiaries identified through monitoring and evaluation of Big Hearts WASH assistance in Idleb City since October 2019. Design of the action also addresses feedback and recommendations from Third Party Monitoring (TPM) of Big Hearts SCHF-funded WASH programming in Idleb City. Specifically, recommendations made to the WASH cluster to assess the possibility of continuing projects to close the water supply gap in Idleb City and increase the number of water tanks distributed. Recommendations regarding gender segregated hygiene promotion activities have already been implemented across Big Hearts WASH programme and will apply to this action, while beneficiary feedback on means to further enhance accountability will also be progressed.
The action is informed by recent technical assessments of targeted water systems completed by Big Heart WASH staff (included under documents) and significant operational experience with both water systems. As such, proposed activities are evidence-based, technically sound and accurately budgeted.

title.narrative: Integrated WASH, and Protection support for people with high risk for COVID19 in northwest Syria

description.narrative: The proposed action will provide an integrated multi sectoral Programme of lifesaving and life sustaining Water Sanitation and ‎Hygiene (WASH) ,and Protection assistance to acutely vulnerable Internally Displaced Persons ‎‎(IDPs) in Dana sub-district targeting 100% IDPs as 10, 758 beneficiaries (2,367 men, 2,475‎ women, 2,904‎ boys and 3,012 ‎girls) including 61 PWD in Idlib governorate, Kafr Deryan and Sarmada in Dana sub district. This is complementary ‎to an already running SCHF funded project in 15 camps in that area which will end in Nov 2020, and through this ‎project, SR will extend supporting 9 camps after Nov 2020 while the rest of 6 camps will be supported through ‎World vision . ‎This intervention will help us complete the activities that Syria Relief started in the same sites a year ago, by provide full WASH ‎service in same camps through WASH project funded by SCHF reserve allocation in Feb 2020, and thus it will make us avoid any ‎gap after SR ‘s project ended in 30 November 2020, Throughout SR WASH team, SR will benefit a total of 10,758 conflict affected people (100% IDPs) which will be as follows: Provide water through water trucking with 35 L/P/D, Collect waste and dislodge waste water- Clean bathing facilities– (SR will monitor the quality of the water through applying the Sphere and Syrian ‎standards). SR will conduct hygiene awareness sessions,‎‏ ‏with integration with Protection team through WASH and Protection ‎promoters, in addition, both CP and WASH teams will work together to provide COVID-19 awareness sessions to all mentioned ‎beneficiaries. SR will Provide Protection services to displaced women and men, including those ‎living with disabilities, most affected by the COVID-19 pandemic and the conflict through targeting them with protection awareness ‎raising activities (GP, CP, RE, GBV) to 4500 beneficiaries (1500 women, 1500 men, 600 Girls and 600 Boys). In addition, SR will ‎provide case management services and individual protection assistance targeting 300 beneficiaries (75 men, 75 women, 75 boys ‎and 75 girls). ‎In collaboration with OCHA, SR will ensure the continuation of basic services, while also increasing access, both in terms of ‎quantity considering needs of PwD amp women and quality (meeting Sphere standards and cluster recommendations) of essential ‎WASH services. Increased focus will be placed on ensuring PwD have access to appropriate sanitation facilities, the Protection ‎concerns of women and girls are considered, and environmental health and hygiene promotion are enhanced. SR will stay in regular contact with the CCCM cluster to make them aware of any change or escalation in beneficiaries’ needs, and ‎will ask for their support if needed.. in case of newly displacements arrived to the targeted camps, SR will contact OCHA to ‎decrease the quantity water for each person 35 L/P/D, and also SR will contact with its HQ to cover the extra needs from its general ‎fund fund and will work with clusters and all partners , this project is part of SR plan in HPC, as the code ( HSYR20-WSH-164602-1)‎

owner-org.narrative: United Nations OCHA Financial Tracking Service (UN OCHA FTS)

reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

description.narrative:
This project will support cross-border operations from Turkey into Syria to tap into sources of information and share it for use by the humanitarian community through a team of humanitarian field officers in NSAG-controlled areas. The team will be managed by the HFOs management team based in Gaziantep, Turkey in consultation with OCHA Turkey. The project is designed to broadly support the formal coordination system, especially the clusters/ICCG, as It is based on four pillars.
1-Information gathering This pillar focuses on gathering data from the ground to produce reports about the humanitarian situation and context and inform response and advocacy. The data is shared with the OCHA coordination unit for use in various platforms and products. Info on unmet needs, including urgent cases, will be shared with clusters to address 2-Support to monitoring of SCHF funded projects. The HFOs will monitor projects funded by the SCHF. These monitoring missions will be conducted upon the request of the SCHF and based on SCHF monitoring criteria. Monitoring of SCHF projects directly improves the quality and accountability of the inter-cluster response, as projects funded by the SCHF are reviewed through the clusters. The HFAs will also receive a training on MampE tools and methods to ensure accurate and relevant information are gathered by them.
3-Community Engagement The HFOs will conduct community engagement to strengthen humanitarian response through facilitating meetings with the affected community and the humanitarian community and other stakeholders obtaining feedback from the community on their needs and the response and providing information to affected people through awareness sessions and other means on the humanitarian response and the community’s rights and role in it. Community engagement informs the overall inter-cluster response and in some cases is organized on behalf of clusters.
4-Service Mapping The existing service map app for mobile phones will get an upgrade to ensure ease of use and better accessibility such as “text-to-speech” for visually impaired people, and more visually-illustrated materials to assist people with reading/writing difficulties. The app will include a virtual information center that will 1)work as an awareness platform disseminating information on key issues such as AAP, COVID-19, and CHS 2)create an accessible repository of information for all affected persons and humanitarian actors to receive support and information to avoid duplication.
The project builds on the outcomes of a previous project completed earlier in 2021. The information-gathering component is well-established and in recent months the mechanism for sharing specific needs data with clusters was streamlined and has resulted in individual cases receiving assistance. SCHF monitoring activities carried out so far have been well-received, resulting in one of the HFOs becoming largely dedicated to this work and the processes for monitoring becoming more formalized which will be further enhanced. Direct engagement with communities facilitated by the HFOs has allowed senior leadership, including the ERC, to provide high-level advocacy from key constituencies including women and PWDs. The service map app is now available in four languages and hosts over than 2,600 distributed between medical, educational emergency, and other types of services. It is also hosting ads from humanitarian actors, and hundreds of people have registered seeking for training. The app has been well received by people in need, clusters, and other stakeholders. Building on this success, BampZ is planning to conduct a promotion campaign to promote the service map application to ensure it is used by the relevant stakeholders as much as possible. A handover plan will also be set to shift the support of the app to another donor to ensure its sustainability.
