reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: Supporting provision of healthcare services through procurement and prepositioning of essential medicine and medical supplies to northwest Syria.

description.narrative:
The proposed project will strengthen access to lifesaving and life-sustaining essential health services within COVID-19 response through procurement of WHO pipeline of PPE supplies to support provision of integrated primary and secondary health care services to the vulnerable population of northwestern Syria. The goal of the project is to assist in procurement and preposition of the medical supplies into the warehouse inside NWS from the WHO pipeline (list of supplies is available as Annex 2) available through the Global Supply portal. According to identified needs WHO is planning to organize direct procurement of medical supplies from the Global Market focusing on specialized emergency health kits, including Inter-agency Emergency Health Basic Kits (IEHK), TESK and NCD kits from WHO Global Emergency Stock in Dubai to be distributed among health facilities in Idleb and Aleppo governates. Regarding COVID-19 response in northwestern Syria WHO will procure supplies both for the laboratories aiming to support surveillance system (laboratory Testing Kits, N95 respirators, and Gown) and health facilities providing specializes medical care to COVID-19 patients through intensive care units (ICU) for confirmed COVID-19 patients with severe symptoms and underlying chronic conditions.
To ensure that these supplies will arrive shortly into NWS, WHO is planning to purchase part of the supplies in Turkey and deliver to Syria immediately since they are under critical demand. Other supplies will be purchased from the available WHO Dubai stock of life-saving supplies and will be based on the existing needs and availability of supplies in Dubai.
Preposition of the procured medicine and medical supplies would be organized through two warehouses in Syria in Aleppo and Idleb governorates, which are operated by two contracted NGOs which will facilitate the distribution of these supplies to the organizations who are managing the health facilities to receive supplies. These are in-kind donations to the health facilities and WHO will not be having services except for logistics and warehouses. Otherwise, all active health cluster partners have been invited to the WHO supply line forum and may get donated supplies to ones who are prioritized based on the need during the months of distribution. The costs of warehousing and logistics will be covered through other WHO funds and will not be charged to this current project.
As well it is worth mentioning that considering the risk of non-renewal of the UN Security Council Resolution it is planned to deliver all goods to NWS before July 10, 2021, and ensure health service continuity,

reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: Enhance Safe Access to Formal Education Services for School-Aged-Children in The Underserved and High-Needs Areas of Atareb, Dana, Darkosh, and Qourqeena Sub-districts

description.narrative:
The proposed intervention's overall objective is to improve equitable access for school-aged children to safe, inclusive, and quality learning environments to foster their resilience. This will be achieved through implementing a package of education activities to 19 formal schools in Atareb, Dana, Darkosh, and Qourqeena sub-districts which are located in underserved and high-needs areas, where11,766 children (5,581 boys and 6,185 girls 'including 302 CwD ~2.5%', 5-17 years old) are enrolled (65% IDPs). The project builds on previous projects' successes, funded by Save the Children, UNICEF, and SCHF. The proposed schools need funding for the time being. So, there will be a big chance for 11,766 school-aged children to lose their education opportunities in addition to 480 education personnel who will lose their only source of income in case these schools aren’t supported. By supporting a quality learning environment, IRD seeks to increase children's enrollment in the targeted schools. To achieve this, IRD will conduct digital Back To Learning (BTL) campaigns 'to minimize gathering and as a precautionary measure for COVID-19' in 14 communities for raising awareness among parents and community members regarding the importance of education. All enrolled students will receive formal education services using the SiG curriculum for 9 months (Sep 21 to May 22). 20% of these students will conduct ASER tests twice. The baseline will be conducted during October 2021 and the end line will be conducted during April 2022 to measure the learning outcomes of the project on students. To improve the students’ well-being during the project lifetime, all enrolled students will receive recreational activities from their classroom teachers. All teachers will be provided with monthly incentives to increase their motivation and ensure their retention in schools. The project will cover the schools’ monthly operational costs, including recreational materials, refreshment, cleaning, hygiene materials, and stationery, conducting light repairs for schools, provision of students' and teachers' kits. The quality of education will be improved through contextualized and targeted teacher training and further support to their professional development within each school by delivering (CSG, TiCC, PSEA, COVID-19) trainings. IRD will cover the costs of these trainings from another funding. Parents Teachers Associations (PTAs) will be a component in the activities of this project. Quarterly meetings for PTAs members will be held to discuss what was achieved in the last period and set with IRD’s staff plans for the upcoming period. Due to COVID-19, there will be comprehensive precautionary measures in the 19 schools, including periodic sterilization process for classrooms and WASH facilities, awareness sessions for students, training for teachers and educational staff, and sterilization provision materials for all schools. IRD will re-utilize all the preexisted IT equipment (laptops and printers) from its previous various education projects.
Plan B: All schools are now operational. In case of COVID-19 out-break again, schools may be suspended and close temporarily. As a plan B, the project will adapt the distance learning modality tested during 2020 through 4 education projects implemented by IRD and provide children with internet vouchers (which will be covered from running costs). WhatsApp groups will be created per subject and per class. Teachers will prepare their lessons and record the lessons to be shared with students. In case there will be a part-time suspension, the blended education approach will be applied. It is a mix of physical attendance and distance learning methods.

reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: Supporting Economic Recovery and Community Resilience in North West Syria

description.narrative:
The project is based on supporting 752 male and female from IDPs and HHS and enhancing their economic capacity by securing income-generating opportunities for them, by providing grants to support projects for 440 male and female with previous experiences or whose projects have been damaged by Covid 19 in addition to providing grants to support projects for 60 people with disabilities (PWD) that suits their disability and re-integrates them into their society, and also by providing vocational training for a 216 male and female and 36 of PWD, followed by a paid employment and internship in the labor market for three months. taking into account their reintegration into society. the project will be in the three locations of Azaz, Dana and Maarat Misrin The project has four intervention : 1st: support projects for 440 (M, F) who have previous experience or have projects affected by COVID-19, where Takaful (TAS) will form 3 Community Representation Committees (CRC) which will receive training to study, evaluate and development of Small-Micro business. The beneficiaries' selection will be in two phases, 220 beneficiaries in each phase, after that monitoring of the local market will be conducted regularly to ensure that no harm was caused, a one-day session will be conducted to explain the mechanism of applying then CRC and Takaful team will evaluate the submitted projects and select best projects, Takaful will provide the final selected beneficiaries with training about ( product study-marketing- accounting,,). The grant will be $1000 and will be cash linked to (assets, tools). Takaful will work to provide the grant in the form of two payments to ensure that the beneficiary is serious.
2nd: Providing Small-Micro Businesses to support 60 PWD (MampF) who have the experience to set up a small income-generating project which fit with their special situation. We will select the beneficiaries and interview them after that The Washington scale will be used, which determines, the percentage of disability, TAS will purchase the needed materials and deliver it in-kind because of their physical difficulties of PWD. The grant amount will be valued at $1,000. The project team will conduct periodical visits to business places to ensure that the businesses are on the path and provide required recommendations. At the end of the two interventions Takaful will provide financial awards with 200 USD to the top 50 projects based on progress, income generated.
3rd: Providing vocational training (VT) for 216 males and females for three months and then provide internships to them in the market for the other three months supported by the project. TAS will update the market needs and needed professions. The appropriate professions and training will according to two groups: 1 the professions which do not require any qualifications. e.g.: Hairdressing, and Sewing. 2 the professions which require relevant experience e.g. Computer Maintenance, Web Development. Three months paid internship will be provided by contracting with the business owners and TAS will provide allowances to the beneficiaries for three months, $88 per month, that will make the beneficiary gain the confidence of the employer and gain practical experience.
4th: Vocational Training for PwDs for 3 months followed by other 3-months paid internship. TAS will secure the necessary transportation back and forth for beneficiaries with disabilities. The PWD beneficiaries will be employed in the market for three months, and the project will provide their allowances with $88 per month.
In the end, a fair job will be held in each of the targeted locations for all beneficiaries to display their products and works to gain the confidence of the local community in their experiences. Related to the Covid-19 pandemic, TAS ensuring all precautionary measures through disinfecting meeting venues before and distributing masks to attendees, printing guiding instructions

reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: Continue the provision of life-saving integrated activities including the basic and secondary formal and non-formal Education, Protection services and WASH-in-schools to the most vulnerable individuals in Northern parts of Syria

description.narrative: The project will support 22 schools in Maaret Tamsrin, Teftnaz, and Dana Sub-districts having high severity scale (21 in camps and 1 in a village) that are funded by HF amp ATAA but will have no funds after May 2021 (attached signed confirmation letters). The project will have integrated services under Education, CP and WASH. Education: The direct beneficiaries will be children in BE amp secondary (1st till 12th grades) including CWDs who will be provided with FE amp NFE, 10427 children (boys 5245, Girls 4910, CWD boys 169, CWD Girls 103) and 463 staff (M:286, F:177). The project will focus mainly on enhancing the infrastructure based on a comprehensive rehabilitation assessment (attached rehabilitation needs) by providing minor rehabilitation to all schools to achieve safe, equitable and protective education considering COVID-19 measures. The project will be cost-efficient as these schools are equipped with furniture, fuel tanks, heaters, book corners, solar panels, and SIG textbook, internet routers, etc, School safety plans include fire extinguishers, first aid kits, evacuation maps, drill and sharing information (banner, brochures, roll-up. Teacher recruitment and incentives payment will be strictly applied by ATAA as they are considered ATAA staff (attached recruitment process), Regular teachers’ observation, TLC meeting, and training to teachers (TICC, Distance Education, SEL, Safe learning). Monthly running cost to schools, COVID-19 schools’ disinfection and PPE provision, to each school. Education process (physically, remotely, blended), apply distance education modality via a digital platform, WhatsApp groups. Summer program for 3 months providing NFE remedial classes, SEL to 1stamp4th grades, Base amp end-line ASER as well as mid and final exams, conduct two rounds of BTS (online/physical), Provide recreational, teachers amp students kits in all in coordination with UNICEF/Shafak Protection: Protection services will deliver to nearly 11700 children and to 1200 of their parents/caregivers and most vulnerable GBWM. Continue CP services, also ATAA will add new services to most vulnerable adults, including elderly and PWDs to ensure inclusive intervention and to leave no one behind. Mitigate the risk of UXOs in targeted locations, deliver emergency services to most vulnerable girls, boys, women and men through 2 static community centers in addition to 4 mobile units, to ensure the safety of beneficiaries all possible precautious measures (social distancing and PPE) and Cluster guidelines related to adapting Protection services delivery modalities in light with COVID-19, Coordination with local service providers from other sectors to facilitate access of PWDs to referral services. Protection services include CP case management, awareness-raising on Covid-19 and Protection/CP issues, parenting programing, supporting community-based child protection committees, case management/child protection trainings, Protection monitoring, and Risk Education. WASH: In the 22 schools, maintain water tanks amp taps to be gender-separated, provide drinkable water on a daily basis (ratio 10 liters/student/day). Rehabilitate latrine units and septic tanks, desludge them regularly for schools that not linked to sewer systems, as well as connect some schools with the main sewer system (attached WASH Activities Table), activate SWM process by providing 88 garbage bins-capacity 100L and collect the garbage on a daily basis from targeted locations. Improve hygienic practices of students by conduct hygiene awareness sessions to 10427 students, conduct 400 raising awareness targeting IDP students along with tailoring special activities for the IDP CWDs (cholera, diarrhea, personal hygiene, leishmaniasis, COVID-19, etc). Choosing 5 children from each school provided with specific clothing to activate their social role as ATFAL Team that will be trained to carry out activities and to create children awareness committees

reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: Scaled-up access to basic food needs in high-needs and underserved areas by providing cash for food and food voucher assistance and creating livelihood opportunities for communities affected by the COVID-19 pandemic.

description.narrative:
The proposed project targets 4 communities in Suran–Aleppo, Azaz and Aghtrin sub-districts, all these camps located in underserved areas, the project consists of two sectors that complement each other:
1- Under FSL: The project target 1123 families with 8 rounds of regular (monthly) food assistance: - Cash for food: GAN will target 1123 families in camps with cash for food, the cash intervention is feasible in these camps as they all have access to different main markets in the targeted communities, eight rounds of cash for food will be distributed between Jul 2021 to Mar 2022, each round consists of two phases, 20 days for distribution and 10 days for validation and PDM, 60$ will be allocated for each family as recommended by FSL cluster and CWG, GAN conducted a deep coordination with different partners working in the same area as detailed in the coordination section, although the data gained form the FSL cluster indicate this areas as high priority ranking and no partner plan to target the same vulnerable and underserved camps, according to the interviews and assessment, 94% said that the first priority is food, the proposed modality is a cash for food, as it is considered one of the most effective modality since the markets are available near camps. Monthly market assessment in terms of availability of the items, prices, and accessibility will be conducted to ensure the local markets are functioning and all beneficiaries have good and equal accessibility to the different goods.
2- Under ERL: GAN through its sub-implementing partner (POINT organization) aims to integrate its intervention and target same affected and most severe communities, IDPs and host communities who are till now relying on aids through provision of livelihood opportunities. The selection of targeted beneficiaries under this ERL component will be from the list of the FSL beneficiaries that will be supported in this FSL intervention and the ones that were supported in the previous FSL project currently being finalized by GAN (SCHF 16291) according to an eligibility and vulnerability criteria with giving priorities to higher vulnerability scores and women headed HHs and PWDs in order to provide a comprehensive integrated intervention.
This will be done by starting with Market mapping to identify market gaps and needs according to which the VT training topics and domains will be identified, then GAN and POINT will start several advocacy and community sensitization activities that aims at engaging the communities, explaining the merits of the intervention and the idea of SMEs, raising awareness of the importance of sustaining small businesses, and clearly communicating the selection criteria in order to reduce the risk of tensions among communities.
After that, the selected beneficiaries will be verified and then will be invited to join the vocational training which will target 100 persons and last for two months on topics that will be identified according to the market mapping with giving priorities to vocations related to PPEs production and other locally produced general covid19 protection related items such as hygiene items. After finishing the VT, Point will deliver SME trainings of five days each for the successful applicants considering their attendance percentage in the VT, tests results and trainers’ evaluations, during this SMEs, the participants will learn about basis of business establishment, marketing financial study, feasibility, competition evaluation.. etc. after that, each participant will submit a business plan which will be evaluated by a formed committee for this purpose. Each successful business plan with the highest scores will be supported with cash grants of 1200$ for the first 78 best plans to be paid on three tranches.

reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: Provision of Regular E-vouchers Food Assistance and MPCA for the most vulnerable people in NW Syria

description.narrative:
**Mercy-USA will target 1799 households in Maaret Tamsrin camps with life-saving and life-sustaining food assistance.
The project consists of two components: 1-Regular food assistance through value based E-Vouchers modality, each HH will receive value 60 USD monthly for 8 months along with the FSL and CWG recommendations to cover the Kcal needs for these households to be aligned with the food component in the SMEB. The E-Vouchers value can be redeemed with list of food items from contracted markets/ shops in the same targeted areas. The beneficiaries in this component will be selected from IDPs who received RTER as response to the flood response in the last winter during January and February (including disabled, female headed households, women and young girls, PLW, and the elderly ) The targeted beneficiaries are 1299 HH (6495 individuals) (Men 1299, Women 1429, Boys 1754, Girls 2013) (from them 625 disabled) Each voucher will be loaded with extra value to purchase 700 gram of soap monthly to be aligned with FSL and WASH cluster for prevention from COVID-19
2- Emergency unrestricted Cash 100 USD as one-off (Multipurpose Cash) for households who affected by any emergencies such as displacement, flood, wind, fire,,,etc 500 HH (2500 individuals) (Men 500, Women 550, Boys 675, Girls 775) (from them 250 disabled)
This intervention is fully aligned with the allocation strategy and FSLamp CWG recommendations by: -Life saving intervention to Scale-up efforts to sustain minimum food consumption needs of the most vulnerable IDPs -The modality is Vouchers and Cash -The value of the voucher is 60 USD for regular (8 months) and 100 USD for emergency (one-off) -Maaret Tasmrin Sub-district is high priority ranking
**Mercy-USA is proposing to contract service provider for the E-vouchers in Turkey to be sub-contracted with markets in the targeted locations, these e-vouchers to be distributed one time for the beneficiaries and to be redeemed regularly on monthly basis. **Accountability to affected population will be given high priority by transparent beneficiary selection criteria, as well ad Complaints and Feedback mechanism which will be in place and accessible to all people through different channels. ** Mercy-USA will have MEAL plan in place in order to monitor the whole process starting from the vulnerability assessment, redemption/ distribution monitoring and post distribution monitoring with corrective measure to be taken on timely manner to ensure continuous improvement of the project implementation in order to reach the planned objectives **Mercy-USA considers the coordination is key aspect to apply complimentary and integration approach by coordination with other NGOs in Maaret Tamsrin Camps in other services as well as complement with other Mercy-USA projects. **Disability inclusion is high priority for Mercy-USA, so many core staff were hired disabled to ensure the inclusion and design all projects by include their perspectives to incorporate inclusion in all phases of projects

reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: Provide of life-saving assistance and support the self-resilience of crisis-affected population in rural of Aleppo.

description.narrative: This project pursuits scaling-up efforts to sustain minimum food consumption needs of the most vulnerable IDPs and host community population in western rural of Aleppo province. This intervention will complement our ongoing project and will make big contribution towards addressing the critical food insecurity and instability of the IDPs in the camps through distribution of free bread as well as supporting the livelihood assets through supporting the wheat value chain and access to agriculture. MASRRAT will Support the local wheat value chain through marketing, wherein MASRRAT has an ongoing project supporting 600 wheat farmers beneficiaries in Aleppo countryside (funded by OCHA). So, MASRRAT will purchase 360 tons of wheat seeds with supported price from the beneficiaries and other farmers (600 kg from each farmer) based on specific criteria for ensuring the pureness of the wheat. The purchased wheat will be used as follows: 1. 240 tons of the purchased wheat will be milled to produce 192 tons of wheat flour and 48 tons of wheat bran (80% + 20% of the purchased wheat seeds) and supply flour directly to bakeries and provide free bread distribution (175.8 tons white bread and 55 tons of bran bread) to 2400 of the most vulnerable IDP HHs for four consecutive months in the targeted locations whose access to subsidized bread is limited. Wherein, MASRRAT will contract with four bakeries to increase the community participation and reduce work pressure and to ensure that the bakeries will not exceed the daily production capacity which will affect the bread quality (part of the resulted wheat bran will be used to cover the costs of milling the wheat flour). 2. The other part of the purchased wheat seeds (120 tons will produce 114 tons of pure wheat after screening, 5% impurities) will be used for improving access to agriculture by distributing it to 456 new wheat farmers. Every beneficiary will receive 250 kg of wheat seeds, one fuel voucher for supplementary irrigation 125 $ as well as three technical training sessions about GAP. The beneficiaries of wheat activity will be from the local community and IDPs who settled for a while, own or renting land between 7 to10 donums suitable for wheat, as well as the farmers who meet the selection criteria. This project will support 14420 beneficiaries affected by the Syrian crisis (3750 men, 3186 women, 3648 boys and 3835 girls including 303 PWDs) by promoting their accessibility to the humanitarian assistance significantly. All the people in the targeted villages and markets will benefit directly/indirectly from the project where the wheat will be available in the markets at normal prices. The project is designed with consideration to the cluster and WHO recommendation on prevention and mitigation measures related to COVID-19 especially during the distribution of support and conducting trainings. In addition, protection cluster recommendations were taken into consideration, wherein all the population in the targeted locations will benefit from MASRRAT protection Centers in Aleppo, in the event of any GBV referral cases. The target villages in Jebel Samman district/Atareb sub-district are considered from the most densely populated areas: Jeineh 6272 HCs amp 2580IDPs Atareb 23950 HCs amp 8632IDPs Kafr Karmin 7100 HCs amp 6000 IDPs Babka 2800 HCs amp 1650 IDPs Abin Samaan 12920 HCs amp 6257IDPs Batbu 4800 HCs amp 5030 IDPs Kafr Naseh Elatareb 3960 HCs amp 7491 IDPs

reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: Provision of life-saving integrated activities including the food distribution to the most vulnerable families in Jarablus District

description.narrative:
The proposed project is designed to scaled-up life-saving assistance, safe and continued access to basic essential services, and the improved protective environment particularly for vulnerable groups such as women and children (2100 HH, 10500 individuals) in Jarablous sub-district which is a high priority ranking in the allocation paper, by providing Life-saving humanitarian assistance to the most vulnerable people with an emphasis on underserved areas with high severity of needs . The assistance will take place in 10 communities taking into consideration equity in access, quality, responsiveness and participation and resilience the intervention can be summarized as the following: FSL Cluster: the project will cover the distribution of Food Rations (2100 FR) for 2500 HH settled in 10 communities for 8 months. These food rations which are according to FSL Cluster standards will be distributed once a month and for 8 months by informing the targeted HHs about the timing and the location as well, taking into consideration the COVID-19 preventive measures such as distributing PPE kits for the teams and distributing soap for the benefited families. This intervention is classified under ASO2 Beneficiaries will be selected based on the proposed vulnerability criteria as reflected below together with other eligibility criteria as determined as follows after coordination with the local authorities: have No food assistance from NGOs. A household with a special needs member. A household with an elderly member. The number of children more than 2. Women-headed HH, or households with a pregnant or lactating woman. Families in need equal to or greater than 5 people The disaggregation of BNFs is as the following For Male Children (0-23mnths) 239 Children (24-59mnths) 478 Children (6-11 yrs) 970 Children (12 -17 yrs) 1180 Adult (18-59 yrs) 1309 Adult 60+: 943 For Female Children (0-23mnths) 334 Children (24-59mnths) 419 Children (6-11 yrs) 1154 Children (12 -17 yrs) 1106 Adult (18-59 yrs) 1155 Adult 60+: 1213 The project will ensure equal access for both genders with the priority for women, children-headed households, disabled persons, chronic disease, PLW, and the elderly in addition the project staff will include female and male members trained on the protection principles and gender equality. Furthermore, ATAA has coordinated with the FSL Cluster and other organizations who are working in Jarablous to avoid any possible duplication and this coordination took place on the 5th of April through documented emails. The project will put in place the prevention and mitigation measures related to COVID-19 during the fieldwork by the physical distance between the beneficiaries during the distribution of baskets.
To summarize the number of benefited families is 2100 HH who will receive on a monthly basis 1 food ration and 1 bar of soap not less than 175G for 8 rounds. Moreover, Concerning families less than 5 members, as WFP partner for 3 years and from the learned lessons, we've faced troubles with the beneficiaries in rotation and splitting the content of the basket or to inform these families that they will only receive the FR each 45 days. Moreover, from the selection criteria is Families in need equal to or greater than 5 people

reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: Enhancing Resilience and Food Security through Supporting Wheat Value Chain and Free Bread Distribution to the neediest people in Northwest Syria during COVID-19 pandemic

description.narrative:
The proposed project aims to support the wheat value chain in Syria through purchasing wheat crops from local farmers and use the purchased wheat in bread production. -1000 tons of wheat crop (650 soft wheat and 350 durum wheat) will be purchased from the Most Vulnerable(MV) farmers in order to support their livelihood and hence their resilience in the following communities: 1- Idleb -Idleb – Idleb- Qminas 2- Idleb -Idleb-Sarmin- Sarmin 3- Idleb-Harim-Armanaz-Ghafar 4- Idleb-Harim-Armanaz-Bsaliya 5- Idleb-Ariha-Mhambal-Al-balah 6- Idleb-Ariha-Mhambal-Ora
-IHH will coordinate with local councils, local authorities and GOSM for selecting up to 250 farmers based on the following selection criteria: Household headed by females up to 30 % of total beneficiaries. Households who have people with disabilities in their families. Large household with 8 or more individuals in the family. Households who have access to farming land from 10 to 20 dunums. Households don't receive any agricultural support from other NGOs for this year. Each farmer can provide 5 ton of wheat seeds at most. Beneficiaries' names, vulnerability and matching selection criteria will be verified before registration. The committee consists of IHHampINSAN team members in addition to agricultural experts will check the quality of the wheat before purchasing it in order to detect its Free of cracking, humidity, Mite insect, fungal diseases and impurities. The 1000 tons of wheat will be sent to the mill to be grinded with extract percentage 75% flour and 25% bran. The produced 750 tons of local flour will be mixed (based on recommended mixture percentage by FSL cluster) with 500 tons of imported flour (durum and soft) provided by IHH as a free contribution to the project. While 250 ton of bran will be used to cover the operational costs of milling wheat. 1250 tons of flour will be sent to the bakery to be baked and produce a total of 2,056,080 free bread bundles, where Each ton of flour produces 1645 bread bundles, the weight of the bread bundle is 700 grams. About 7908 free bread bundles will be distributed daily to 4669 HH’s in 37 camps in Maaret Tamasrin subdistrict for 26 days / monthly up to 10 months from 1/7/2021 to 30/4/2022 in the following communities: - Kaftin 3 camps (599 H.Hs–3315 individuals) - Kafr–Kafrehmul 14 camps (1539 H.Hs-9017 individuals) - Kelly 17 camps (2173 H.Hs–11505 individuals) - Maaret Elekhwan 3 camps (358 H.Hs–1951 individuals)
Distribution criteria will be: HH with 1 - 4 individuals will receive one bread bundle. HH with 5 - 8 individuals will receive two bread bundles. HH with 9 and above will receive three bread bundles.
IHH will be responsible for purchasing 1000MT of wheat, contracting a mill to grind wheat, storing the flour in a warehouse, contracting a bakery to bake 1250MT of flour (750MT of flour produced from milling 1000MT of wheat, and 500MT of flour provided by IHH as free contribution in the project) and to transport bread to distribution centers. While IC will be responsible for selecting beneficiaries of IDPs in the camps and distributing free bread to 4669 HHs in 37 camps up to 10 months, coordination with camps managers in the targeted areas of bread distribution where it will sign MOU with them before the start of the project. Also IC will be responsible for conducting field visits and monitoring the work at distribution sites, mill and bakery. The project will assist and contribute to the food security of the MV groups of women, men, girls and boys in all age groups and disabled people in the targeted communities. Beneficiaries have been involved in project designing and will be involved in implementation through close coordination with the local council and community representatives, also beneficiaries will be engaged in evaluation through satisfaction survey and complaint mechanism.

reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: Scale-up efforts to sustain minimum food consumption needs of the most vulnerable IDPs through daily bread distribution for 18964 IDPs in camps in high and medium priority in Harim and Salqin areas for 7 months.

description.narrative:
Without adequate resources and due to the general economic deterioration in northwest Syria, people in need have continued to resort. The proposed project aims to Scale-up efforts to sustain the most vulnerable IDPs' minimum food consumption needs through Supply flour or bread directly to bakeries and provide free bread distribution in areas with limited access to subsidized bread in sub-districts in NW Syria.
The proposed project will serve a total population of 18964. IDPs ( 4659 Men, 5191 women, 4760 Boys, and 4354 girls) in Harim (4.3 high priority area) and Salqin ( 3.9 Medium priority area) according to the 2021 1st allocation paper in 21 IDPs camps and settlements. The proposed project is a continuation of last year's SKT project in the same locations. SKT has access to IDPs' information and needs. Thus, the proposed project will be a continuation of the cluster plan to support the food security of the most vulnerable groups in NWs. The target locations have not received any food assistance from the distributed free bread during the last 2 years. The proposed free bread distribution project is the only project that partially covers the daily 2100 calories needs of the target IDPs. Suspending these services will create a huge gap and will harm the food security of these IDPs.
According to the needs assessment results and the coordination that SKT has implemented with the other key organizations in the same target area, and as addressing to 3PM recommendation, SKT will start increasing the weight of the bread bundles to 0.9 KG. The coordination has been made with NWS FSL cluster coordination, Goal organization, and Hand in Hand to improve the technical aspects of bread distribution activities. Further coordination was done with Insan, IHH, and Mercy without limits to ensure no duplication or overlapping in targeting IDPs.
SKT will conduct a procurement process for flour from inside Syria - as cluster and HF recommendation- SKT team to be transferred to the bakery. SKT will provide the operational cost for the bakery for the flour to be baked. It will provide the nylon bags, each ton of flour will provide 1277 bread bundles with 900gr for each with criteria (900gr for each family with members of 5 and less and 1.8kg for each family with members of 6 and more daily). SKT will monitor transferring the bread from the bakery to the distribution points (5 distribution points) through special cars prepared for bread transferring to save the quality of the bread (the distance between the bakery and the distribution points will not be more than 7 km maximum and the distance between each distribution point and the targeted beneficiaries will not be more than 1 km maximum), the volunteer will monitor and supervise the distribution process, a monitoring process will be conducted for the number of bread bundles baked, the weight of bread bundles, the quality of the bread bundles through three levels (the first one in the bakery by the bakery officer, the project officer, and the project assistant and through the volunteers in each distribution point daily, an external monitor from each camp will attend the distribution process, and s/he will monitor the quality and quantity of the bread distributed. Each level of the monitoring process, including the external monitor, will be reported daily, contained signed papers, and reported to the Turkey-based project manager to match all it together. A card with a serial number that matches with the SKT database received by hand with the same beneficiary will be distributed for each family monthly.
COVID-19 prevention measures recommended by the FSL cluster will be taken into consideration while implementing the project activities.
SKT has developed an integrated MEAL and Risk Management plans. PSEA reporting and BNF feedback system are active and functional.

reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: Integrated Food Security and Emergency Nutrition response to the most vulnerable conflict-affected IDPs in Al Bab, Aghtrin, Jarablus and Ghandorah sub-districts

description.narrative: The project is supporting the food security intervention through distribution of free bread to the IDPs HH in Al-Bab, Aghtrin, Jarablus, and Ghandorah sub-districts, with Nutrition-sensitive response to enhance the food security and nutrition. The project aims to support 8,524 IDP households (42,924 individuals: 8,256 men, 9,399 women, 13,279 boys, 11,990 girls) in 18 camps in Al-Bab, Aghtrin, Jarablus and Ghandorah sub-districts in Aleppo governorate with free bread distribution in an average of 1 bundle with 800-gram weight for families with 5 members and fewer and 2 bundles with 800-gram weight for families with more than 5 members per day for continuous 140 days over 5.5 months. To achieve that, BINAA will contract with 4 bakeries from the surrounded area and will provide them with wheat flour and operational costs to prepare the daily needed quantities of bread in order to be distributed to the targeted camps over 27 distribution points. The distribution will be under the supervision of BINAA field staff (Males and females) and support from the representatives from the local communities. The project was designed as a continuation to provide free bread distribution to the targeted families who were receiving support through a previous project funded by OCHA until the beginning of April 2021. this was according to the analyses of the needs’ assessment and FGDs conducted by Binaa which shows the continuity of the need. (refer to Attachment 01-02-04). BINAA field team will conduct verification visits to 100% of the 18 camp's residents to add the new arrivals and exclude who left the camps, and this verification will be conducted on monthly basis to ensure the exact number of families and provide them with the assistance. Binaa will start early procurement in order to fill the gap of stop provision of assistance early in the project period, so Binaa can start the bread provision on time, however, the all the contracting will be after signing the agreement. BINAA will conduct awareness campaign on the best practices towards COVID-19, mechanisms for reporting violations (GBV and SEA), and access to service, health, nutrition and protection centers. the campaign will conduct through expert team from the protection staff, (majority of the staff will be women) to cover youth, women, elderly and PWD. Through the project Binaa will formulate 8 Nutrition Rapid Response Teams (RRTs) to support 46 location in Al-Bab, Jarablus, and Ghandorah Sub-District (Attachment 27), whilst BINAA is already operating 1 RRT in Aghtirin Sub-District since February 2021 supported by UNICEF to the end of December 2021. Hence, the maximized impact of Nutrition Activities with the FSL interventions will be expanded to reach 11 camps in Aghtrin during the project. The RRTs will reach 13,506 families of the newly IDPs. The RRTs will Provide the Nutrition Services of integrated CMAM, IYCF, IMCI with adaptations COVID-19 to reach 5,363 PLWs, and 14,392 CU5. In addition to supporting the engagement of 18% of the targeted families in the FSL program at the food distribution points with scaled-up IYCF-E, WaSH, and Health integrated awareness-raising sessions (1070 families/5280 individuals). BINAA field team will take all preventing precautions from COVID-19 during the implementation as per the recommendation of Nutrition Cluster, UNICEF, COVID-19 Taskforce, and WHO Monitoring and Evaluation activities will be conducted throughout the project which will include: Distribution Monitoring, Verification visits, and PDM. 5 camps out of the 18 were not coded by CCCM cluster, so we started the registration process, and the related email is attached, attachment 05.

reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: Cash Based Emergency Assistance and Livelihoods in Afrin and A’zaz

description.narrative:
The main goal of the proposed project is to deliver immediate humanitarian assistance to the most vulnerable IDP people in camps and member of host communities (HC) in Afrin complemented with a livelihoods activity to improve the resilience of 50 households through small grants. It addresses the overarching aim “to ensure effective use of SCHF resources and inherent added value to achieve maximum impact through provision of humanitarian assistance to the most vulnerable people, while ensuring cost efficiency and closer integration of interventions.” Therefore, WHH chose the most cost efficient modalities, to reach as many people as possible. The project is in line with the strategic objectives ASO 2 “Life-saving humanitarian assistance and protection to the most vulnerable people with an emphasis on underserved areas with high severity of needs.” and ASO3: “Enhance resilience of affected communities through provision of livelihood opportunities.” The project addresses the clusters FSL, WASH and Early Recovery in target areas Afrin (FSL, WASH, ER) and A’zaz (A’zaz) und the locations Bablit, Baee, Jandairis, Kawkabeh, Sharan, Suran, and Zahrat Elhayat. The project intends to integrate livelihood, food security and wash using cash as a modality. In North-West Syria (NWS), the price of basic food commodities remains volatile and is subject to speculation. Disruptive events, specifically displacement and COVID-19 have harmful and immediate consequences on the households’ economy and may result in reduced consumption and exclusion, requiring the adoption of a framework of priorities and actions that are focused on livelihoods. Proposed intervention has 2 components:(1) distribution of cash to internally displaced persons(IDPs) in camps and vulnerable HC members to cover their urgent lifesaving needs (2) Small grants for 50 women to improve their resilience towards external shocks through a sustainable livelihood. The primary objective of the activity is to ensure that vulnerable families have access to food and WASH items to fulfill the immediate needs. Cash will be provided through a money transfer agent following procedures agreed in SoPs including C19 preventive measures. Value of cash transfers will be $90 per HH for 8 months, following cluster recommendations. The activity will be implemented in/off camps in Afrin, Jandairis, Sharan sub-districts and Suran Sub-district as well. The activities proposed are aligned with ASO2 (FSL) and ASO3 (WASH) of this standard allocation. Complementary to the above proposed component, WHH aims at improving the resilience of 50 women through the provision of small business grants. Each grant will be worth 900 USD and enable the beneficiaries to start her own small business. Potential areas of business are textile, handcrafts, livestock, agriculture, and others. The women will receive a training that educates the beneficiaries in (a) basic profit/loss accounting and (b) marketing. WHH will further assist with market analysis. To avoid that the grant is used for ineligible own-consumption purposes, the grants will be provided in two tranches. After completing the first phase of the activity, the grantees will receive the second tranche. Moreover, the women will be assisted for eight months with cash vouchers in line with the activity introduced above. The activity proposed is aligned with ASO3 (WASH CVA) of this standard allocation. The following cluster specific objectives will be addressed:
ASO 2: FSL: Scale-up efforts to sustain minimum food consumption needs of the most vulnerable IDPs ASO 3: 1 ERL: Integrated sectoral response for livelihoods creation 2 WASH: Cash-based programming to enhance access to WASH supplies and services

reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: Provision of life-saving Education and Health assistance to the most affected population in NW Syria.

description.narrative:
Shafak is proposing to implement an integrated health and education intervention, that aims at ensuring the continuity of essential health and education services in NWS through promoting equitable access and quality of education and health services for people and school children. An integrated approach will be ensured through linking the targeted beneficiaries from both components for instance, supported children with education will be served and/or referred as necessary to the targeted health facilities, and will be supported with awareness-raising on key health messages including hygiene issues and COVID-19. Furthermore, this action will be complemented with other health, nutrition, education, and protection assistance services provided by Shafak and other actors operating in the same areas.
The proposed intervention will target 61,303 people (22,164 IDPs, and 39,139 HC) including 11,846 men, 17,577 women, 15,908 boys, 15,972 girls, of them 1,756 people with disabilities. The project will be implemented in the Suran and Aghtrin sub-district of Azaz district in the Aleppo governorate and in Dana, Qourqeena, and Salqin sub-districts in Idleb governorate.
The following services will be provided through this action:
1) Health:
Shafak will continue supporting a comprehensive package of health and outreach services including Primary Health Care (PHC) and community health awareness services in two of the existing facilities, currently supported by GIZ until the end of April 21, in Azaz District. The following facilities will be supported based on Shafak assessment, updated HeRAMS, and recommendation from Aleppo Health Directorate:
Aghtrin PHC center, (HF-Code: B0204077) Ziadiyah PHC center, (HF-Code: B0204066)
Building on the already established and equipped centers, experienced teams, Shafak will continue providing static health services, outreach, and referrals, focusing on the most vulnerable of women, boys, girls, and PwDs. The services include pediatric, reproductive health (RH), nutrition, management of communicable and non-communicable diseases, providing essential medicines and medical supplies, and will be implemented in line with WHO guidelines (Pillar 9 of COVID 19 Preparedness and Response Plan).
The health services will target 52,922 people including 11,643 men, 17,465 women, 11,642 boys, and 12,172 girls.
2) Education:
Shafak will provide safe equitable access to 4 non-formal and 12 formal education in Azaz district in the same locations targeted under health intervention, and in Harim district. The main activities are as follows:
1. Non-Formal Education services in four learning centers in Harim district through classroom learning modality (with plan B to resort to distance learning modality, based on developments of COVID 19). These No-formal catch-up classes will run in one cycle in summer to allow the transition to formal education, using the Syrian Interim Government (SIG) curriculum.
2. Formal education services in 12 schools in Harim and Azaz districts at the beginning of the school year 2021/2022 through physical classroom attendance modality.
3. Psycho-social Support (PSS) sessions for school children using (I-DEAL) curriculum in formal and non-formal settings endorsed by UNICEF and CP sub-cluster.
4. Establishing Parent-Teacher Associations (PTAs).
5. Light maintenance and improvement of learning spaces while considering gender-sensitive and disability-friendly WASH facilities.
6. Teacher’s Professional Development delivered to 256 teachers (154 male, 102 female) on EiE, PSEA, and PSS, along with providing monthly incentives to education personnel.
The education activities will target 9,734 crisis-affected children (5,197 boys and 4,537 girls) including CwDs along with 403 education personnel (260 men, 143 women).
The Integrated approach has been detailed in the Coordination and Complementarity Section due to characters count limit.

reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: Supporting the Provision of Life-Saving and Life-Sustaining Healthcare Services for the Conflict Affected Population in Need Within Harim District.

description.narrative:
In line with the SCHF 2021 SA1 allocation- ASO2 objective (To provide Life-saving humanitarian assistance and protection to the most vulnerable people with an emphasis on underserved areas with high severity of needs) and in response to the demonstrated needs and gaps in health service provision for the conflict- affected population within Harim district, Human Appeal Turkey (HAT) proposes to support and sustain the functionality of two healthcare facilities in the district for a duration of 12 months, namely:
“Iman” maternity hospital in Sarmada/ Dana sub-district/ Harim district/ Idleb governorate (HeRAMS identifier code: G0703086). Human Appeal Mobile Clinic in Sarmada IDPs camps/ Dana sub-district/ Harim district/ Idleb governorate (HeRAMS identifier code: B0200196).
The above facilities will continue providing primary and secondary healthcare services for around 79,560 people in need within their catchment area as follows: RH outpatient consultations in both facilities. Pediatric outpatient consultations in both facilities. General medicine outpatient consultations in HAT MC. Community health awareness services in both facilities Provision of essential medicines in both facilities. Referral capacity in both facilities. CEmONC services, laboratory services, inpatient healthcare for the women of reproductive age and newborns in Iman hospital.
Also, Iman hospital serves as an operation station for 2 vaccination teams operated by HAT and another 2 teams by ACU. Furthermore, IYCF-E and CMAM services are being provided through the hospital as well.
The proposed facilities are operating in Dana sub-district that is classified by the allocation paper among the areas of highest humanitarian severity scores. Also, and as per the HNAP report, more than 77% of Dana inhabitants are IDPs who in turn are among the most vulnerable individuals that need humanitarian assistance (This is confirmed by the previous caseloads at both facilities as 93% of beneficiaries served through Iman hospital and almost 100% of those served through the mobile clinic were IDPs). Furthermore, the healthcare services planned to be provided at both facilities mainly target women of reproductive age, children under 18 as well as elderly individuals that are all considered among the most vulnerable population groups.
Besides referring to the health cluster/ Turkey hub dashboard health facilities map, and for the purpose of ensuring coordinated and non-duplicating intervention, HAT, during the design phase, was very keen to coordinate and communicate with the partners and coordination bodies relevant to project including the health cluster, Idleb health directorate, SRH TWG, and Sham foundation that is operating a pediatric specialized hospital in Sarmada, the same community where “Iman” hospital is based.
In addition to the above service package, and to ensure integration of COVID-19 related preparedness and response measure, HAT proposes to maintain the operations at the COVID-19 triage station at Iman hospital for the whole project period. This will help the facility to mitigate the risk of COVID-19 transmission and infection among the staff and the beneficiaries.
In order to promote the cost efficiency of SCHF matched funds, HAT will provide co-funding of around 175,000 USD to support the provision of all medicines, medical and lab supplies, the majority of project support staff remuneration costs needed for ensuring the smooth implementation of the proposed activities and provision of the planned healthcare services. Accordingly, the cost per medical procedure matched to this application will be around 7.76 USD (Or 9.96 USD considering HA co-funding), where both values are considered to be highly efficient against the average cost of around 10-12 USD across NW- Syria.

reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

description.narrative:
Over a seven-month period, SAMS will leverage its technical and operational expertise, to maintain the critical minimum functionality of COVID 19 dedicated hospitals in line with the recommendations of the COVID-19 Taskforce prioritization analysis to decrease the mortality rate by increase the accessibility of the community to essential and lifesaving’ health interventions. With a total of 21,592 confirmed cases (of them 1,346 are active cases) and 1157 confirmed cases in Jabal Samaan district (as of 14 April 2021, EWAR/ACU), SAMS will support Al Amal specialized facility in northwest Syria, Jebel Saman district of Aleppo (HeRAMS code: B0200097), for treating and isolating the severe and critically ill patients. The hospital has been functioning as a hospital-based isolation unit (HBIU) since October 2020, and treated until March 2021, 577 patients (60% Male, 40% Female) and is still receiving such cases now (The most affected age groups are patients over 60 years (approximately 60%), whereas the affected patients under 18 years were 2%, and the other affected age groups were 38%).
Al Amal hosts the highest number of those cases according to the daily update from the Health Information System team (HIS). It is the only HBIU in Jabal Samaan District, an easily accessible facility, and serves around 15 communities in the Jebel Saman district in Aleppo governorate, in addition to one community in Dana sub-district in Idleb governorate, with a total catchment population amounts to 152,154 persons (54,853 IDPs), who may benefit from its services. The isolation hospital is divided into 3 departments as follow: ICU Department: 30 ICU beds, provides care to critically severe COVID-19 patients, the department is equipped with 30 monitors, 30 ventilators, oxygen output for each bed. IPD Department: 40 beds, includes patient assessment, monitoring, routine lab investigation, x-ray, and supportive therapy and treatment.
The hospital is well equipped with all the needed equipment including Ultrasound cardiac, X-Ray, ECG machine, Video laryngoscopes, incinerator, and oxygen generator. Also, the hospital has 10 additional monitors in the hospital as we already planning to activate an Intermediate Intensive care unit.
As for the staff, Al Amal hospital has 16 doctors (15 internists and 1 on-call intensivist) in addition to 30 ICU technicians working in the ICU department, 24 nurses, 15 IPC workers, and many other medical and non-medical staff. Al Amal COVID-19 designated hospital is linked with 3 community-based treatment centers (CCTCs) in the area 2 CCTCs in Daret Ezza and 1 in Alatareb which are run by SDH (Alseeraj) and it coordinates to receive cases from those centers, in addition, Alamal hospital is coordinating with HIS team and submitting daily information. Moreover, the hospital is part of the COVID-19 referral network to receive suspected/confirmed severe and critical cases. The project included supporting the salaries of medical and non-medical staff in addition to the facility running cost, consumables, medication, and any other needed materials. By the end of the project period, SAMS estimates treating a total of 1,029 beneficiaries (560 men, 433 women, 19 boys, 17 girls), of them 309 IDPs

reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: Provision of life-saving healthcare services by supporting Two key health facilities in Idlib district.

description.narrative:
This project will reflect the SDH's strategy to ensure the adequate coverage of the essential healthcare package to the targeted people in need of humanitarian assistance in Northern West Syria within the SDH's plan coverage area in 2021, which the number of total people in need has increased from 2.8 to 3.4 million people in this year, where the humanitarian needs in northwest Syria continue to be driven by the impacts of over a decade of hostilities exacerbated by economic deterioration and multiple displacements. on the other hand, the COVID-19 pandemic impact has further complicated the lives of people in humanitarian settings in northwest Syria. while considering the health system in NWS is still fragile with an urgent need for continuous support. regarding these settings, and in order to Maintain the essential healthcare services, where the currently supported health facilities, are providing the essential required medical consultations, examinations amp diagnosis, along with prophylactic amp therapeutic medications. So, according to SDH plan insight of its HRP 2021, SDH is proposing to continue supporting the health sector in Idlib district, by this project which aims to support the current health system by keeping the flow of medical supervision to the most vulnerable people through supporting three health facilities (2 PHCs) to be able to continue providing the essential healthcare services to the targeted populations as follows:
1- Muhambel PHC (G0705035) In Idleb, Ariha, Mhambal (Average score: 3.2 /Priority ranking: Med): providing approximately 5500 consultations monthly, covering more than 50,000 Ind (host), with more than 12,000 Indv(IDPs + returnees). providing essential OPD services as well as dentistry, lab tests, and medications. with 355,055.21 USD for 1-year full support (54% of total budget).
2- Bab El-Hawa PHC (G0703148) In Idleb, Harim, Dana (Average score: 5.0 /Priority ranking: High): providing approximately 2000 consultations monthly, covering more than 31,000 Ind (IDPs). from Bab El-Hawa camps, providing the essential OPD services as well as medications through its pharmacy. with 302,454.44 USD for 1-year full support (46% of total budget D.C).
SDH will also support the staff’s capacity-building through training especially for the health staff such as continuous on-job coaching as well as the NCD last approved protocols, and encouraging the empowering of women's role in this project. SDH's aims to Sustaining and expanding essential, quality health services at community and primary care levels by the efforts of CHWs components in this intervention. Likewise, availability and accessibility of essential, emergency, and specialized health services to meet the needs of the most vulnerable groups. this intervention from the SDH organization is well designed based on recent Needs assessments done by the SDH field team, to fill the gaps of supporting the current healthcare services in the targeted areas, with close coordination with local authorities and Idlib health directorate as well as the health cluster and technical respective WGs.

reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: Increase access to essential health services in NW- Syria

description.narrative:
This project aims to continue accessibility to essential life-saving health services to address the dire and increasing needs of health services for all age and sex groups boys, girls, women, and men, with attention to people with special needs physical disability, elderly, people with chronic diseases and psychosocial problems without any sexual discrimination, among IDPs and host communities, in NW Syria, Where the project will provide health services for 36385 beneficiaries (12970 men, 12700 women, 5280 boys, 5435 girls) (21979 IDPs and 14346 HCs,60 Returnees) (1090 PWDs) including all age groups children, adolescences, young adults, middle-aged adults, and older adults.
These objectives will be achieved by continue supporting the already existed and functioning Harim General hospital (HeRAMS code G0703149), located in Harim subdistrict which crowded with IDPs, it is now considered one of the most crucial facilities in NW Syria covering more than 100,000 people, this hospital is already funded by SCHF, and this project aims to continue providing essential health care services including: Provision of integrated primary health care services as per the Essential Health Service Package (EHSP) through the outpatient unit. Provision of outpatient consultation Provision of prevention and control of NCDs, provide an adaptive response that is required to account for the needs of people with NCDs according to NCD- COVID 19 guideline. provision of essential medicines, medical supplies, and equipment for direct beneﬁciaries, focusing on the essential medicine list of EHSP. Provision surgical, trauma, injury care, minor and major surgeries with attention to acute medical emergencies requiring immediate surgical intervention. Provision of hospitalizing services. Provision of intensive health care services through support ICU. Integrate WASH services, particularly medical waste management, save water provision, hand hygiene resources, etc. Integrate PSS services through conduct awareness sessions about mental health issues and aspects related to COVID 19 response. Ensure referral pathways for cases that need further management through coordination on a high level with referral network. operate the central oxygen concentrator to supply the health facilities in surrounding area with oxygen cylinders in coordination with health directorate
In addition, this project aims to continue supporting Afrin blood bank (HeRAMS Code B0203082) located in Afrin city. The only blood bank that covers Afrin district in Aleppo governorate, monthly it provides blood components for 400 patients including women, men, boys, and girls, the supported cases include major surgeries, acute hemolytic anemia, acute hemorrhages, chronic anemia, thalassemia, as well as normal and C-section deliveries, it will provide treatment of thalassemia patients including chelating therapy and medications interventions.
The project will contribute to the response to limit transmissions of COVID 19 in NW Syria, through applying triage protocol, providing extra PPE, and applying precautions measures to protect the staff and patients in accordance to triage and IPC- COVID-19 guideline, Integrate RCCE to enhance prevention and reduce risk of spread of COVID-19 by improve community compliance and adherence with updated recommendations and procedures, and encourage beneficiaries to have COVID vaccination as vaccination campaign is coming.
SDI will monitor the quality and accountability to ensure the activities meets the standards, the supply chain department will ensure all needed equipment and operational supplies are delivered on time. SDI will provide quantitative and qualitative reports that include disaggregated information about cases/age, sex, gender, and disability.

reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: Strengthen the referral system and referral data management unit in Northern Syria

description.narrative:
This project seeks to strengthen the referral system and the referral data management unit (RDMU) especially in light of the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic, and it is a part of the response to the increased needs of conflict-affected people in NWS including the hosts and IDPs who suffer from bad situation related to health and economy and, to support the overall dire humanitarian situation in the region, which contributes to saving lives and reducing the proportion of morbidities. The prioritized need in this regard is to sustain the functionality of the referral system through the provision of the fuel for 60 ambulances within the central referral system in northern Syria as well as enhancing the referral data management unit (RDMU) as a main unit in the Health Information System (HIS) to ensure the sustainability and quality of health services, as follows: - Securing the fuel for 60 ambulances for emergency cases and to operate 4 cold cases vehicles to transfer patients who need non-emergency medical consultations or referred between the HFs across different levels of healthcare for further medical investigations or treatment. Under the referral component, capacity building for the referral focal points of 75 HFs will be done to include them in the central referral system's direct coordination and supervision mechanism. Where the central referral network will coordinate referrals through 60 ambulances and 4 cars to transport cold cases between 75 health facilities distributed in Idlib, Hama, and Aleppo governorates at a rate of 3,600 referrals per month. - Supporting and expanding the Referral Data Management Unit (RDMU) of the Central Health Information System specialized in collecting, processing, and analyzing referral system data. This will be in coordination with the WHO three networks: Harim, Afrin, and Northern Aleppo. The data of 24,000 referred cases from 65 different health facilities will be reported to the RDMU within HIS during the proposed period of the project.
The total number of beneficiaries from this project will be 67,758, as follows: - # of referred patients by the ambulances and the cold-case vehicles: 43,200 - # of referral focal points trained on referral SoPs: 250 - # of RDMU staff: 8 - # of referred patients whose data have been reported to the RDMU through the 65 hospitals: 24,000 - # of NGOs staff attended RDMU workshops: 300
Please find the following attached annexes: - Annex 1- Referral System: Includes the ambulances' positioning points of the referral system. - Annex 2- HFs report to RDMU

reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: Improving Access to Trauma, Secondary, and primary Healthcare Assistance for Conflict-affected Syrians in Northern west Syria.

description.narrative: Syrian Expatriates Medical Association (SEMA) aims to increase access of affected population in North West Syria to primary, secondary, and trauma services in Idlib governorate, the project’s objectives will be attained through supporting Waseem Hsaino hospital in Idleb, which provides integrated life-saving health, nutrition, and protection services to all age and sex groups boys, girls, women, and men, with attention to people with special needs physical disability, elderly, people with chronic diseases and psychosocial problems without any discrimination, among IDPs and host communities in NW Syria in general and in Kafar takharim area in particular. SEMA-targeted HF will receive support in the form of payment of salaries for HF staff (medical and non-medical), monthly operational costs, professional training and monitoring, provision of pharmaceuticals, and other medical and non-medical commodities (including equipment, medicines, and consumables). SEMA support will ensure the provision and continuation of integrated health, nutrition, and protection package services. In recognition of the risks and urgent needs associated outbreak of COVID-19 in NW Syria, SEMA will provide coordinated assistance to conflict-affected communities, alongside focusing on infection prevention and control through different measures taken for health staff and patients in the health facilities. Triage spaces are already established in front of the identified health facilities. Trained staff will screen persons for COVID-19 and detect and refer suspected COVID-19 cases according to the WHO and Taskforce guidelines. Moreover, awareness raising messages will be distributed to the patients and care givers to ensure risk communication and community engagement. SEMA will collect health data from the HFs monthly and share it accordingly. All SEMA - targeted HFs are part of the EWARN network and report weekly bulletin to EWARN regularly. SEMA will provide the capacity building, and ongoing medical supervision to ensure the target HFs are staffed with qualified medical personnel and enhance compliance with standard treatment protocols. SEMA will continue to provide training to the HFs on various health topics, either by conducting training or securing training opportunities through inter-agency opportunities. Including management of communicable and non-communicable diseases, pharmaceutical supply management, patient data management, and gender-sensitivity and protection. The hospital is one of the largest hospitals in northern Idleb, and provides its services through ER, OPD, IPD and operations departments. The hospital has a capacity of 23 beds in the various departments, in addition to the pharmacy and laboratory. The hospital is fully accessible for people with disabilities and older people, as the building of the hospital is prepared with all the measures to facilitate the reception of these beneficiaries (Ramps, chair wheels..), the stairs have a hand-rail, in addition that the water closets are also equipped with flip up grab bar to address PwDs needs. As the hospital was supported through SEMA private fund after the end of the previous support, from SCHF on 22nd of November 2020, and the hospital was supported with the minimum, so the beneficiaries’ number were estimated as when the project was supported by SCHF as an average of three months were taken into consideration, where the total number of beneficiaries was about 4847 (1879 men, 1478 women, 920 boys and 570 girls) 2948 hosts and 1899 IDPs. During the first quarter of 2021, Waseem Hsaino hospital provided the following consultations as follows: - Waseem Hasino: # of consultation (11458), # of IDPs (3895), # of females (5039) and # of children under 5 (2020).

reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: Increase life-saving and resilience of the most vulnerable groups in northwest Syria through improved access to primary and specialized health service and a community-based resilience building

description.narrative: The project will build on previous achievements of the SCHF and continue to provide integrated supports (health and protection) to the vulnerable groups in an accessible way. The project complements other on-going HIHFAD projects funded by ECHO,and contribute to a broader coverage of comprehensive health/protection services such as PHCs network. Built on HIHFAD’s previous success in harnessing self-reliance among the most marginalized group as well as in promoting disability inclusive approach among the humanitarian organisations and the communities, the proposed project aims at increasing resilience of the persons with disabilities and IDPs through community and beneficiary participation. A PHC provides life-saving,critical health services to women,children,people with non-communicative diseases and elderly,in addition to essential LAB services,with transportation for referrals.Kalbeet PHC in Alamal Camps (the camp has been managed by TRC) and catchment area of other 12 camps.Services includes:women health–Children Health-elderly health through–the mentioned services are supported by Lab services and a pharmacy -also out reach activities will be through 4 CHWs. other services in the rounded communities ,Babl Alhawa Hospital is operated by SAMS,.Alameen PHC.For the near communities such as Atmeh and Dana HIHFAD is operating 2 general hospitals and one Maternity and children hospital. Albab physiotherapy centre offers comprehensive specialised health service including physiotherapy, PSS, orthopedic consultancies, peer supports, speech and hearing therapy and case management in order to ensure health access and to enhance protection of the persons with disabilities, transportation for people with disability.For COVID-19 HIHFAD developed an SOP related to this issue and shared it with the relevant technical working group (details uploaded as a document).Assistive devices and medical consumables will be provided to patients according to the needs identifiedby the qualified physiotherapists and case workers. Enhance participation of the persons with disabilities through the community inclusion networks and promotion of disability inclusion approach among non-protection actors/NGOs, such as Education, CCCM, WASH, FSL, ER. In addition to existing 14 community networks for disability inclusion, the project will add one more network, and all of them will further progress towards community-based rehabilitation (CBR) mechanism and act as ‘champions’ on disability inclusion via -Engage schools to build disability inclusion capacity at education facilities through peer supports and child resilience activities -Provide training and awareness sessions on inclusion of people with disabilities in communities -Identify and refer people with disabilities -Become an agent of advocacy in their communities for rights of people with disabilities -Plan and conduct community events of their choices -Conduct accessibility audits in selected camps/IDP sites/schools Address barriers to socio-economic opportunities and livelihood through customized supports of their choices for the persons with disabilities with case managements, apprenticeship programme and engagement of the private sector. -300 beneficiaries and their families among the most vulnerable households will benefit through case management, protection assistance, referrals, and access to socio-economic activities. -Engage the private sector on inclusive employment awareness raising and conduct barrier mapping) -Apprenticeship will offer training and working experiences with other organization on substituted salary while the beneficiaries can gain competitive working skills and knowledge.Upon the completion of apprenticeship, HIHFAD will promote inclusive employment among other humanitarian agencies, and it will advocate cooperating organisations to retain them. Evidences on supports for socio-economic opporounity are missing globally, particularly in northwest Syria.

reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: Providing emergency nutrition, health, and protection services for displaced children under 5 and PLWs by RRTs in northwest Syria

description.narrative:
This project will cover 61,239 people, disaggregated as follows: - 22,051 PLWs - 39,188 Children under 5 (20,055 girls - 19,133 boys)
15 rapid response teams (RRTs) will provide integrated nutrition, health, and protection life-saving services in the targeted areas and camps (Attached) in Idleb gt Ariha gt Mhambal gt Bales / Beftamun / Hila / Idleb gt Harimgt Armanaz gt Hafasraja - Kabta - Kuwaro - Um Elriyah Idleb gt Harimgt Dana gt Kafr Deryan Idleb gt Harimgt Qourqeena gt Barisha- Kafr Aruq - Qourqeena - Ras Elhisn Idleb gt Harimgt Salqin Idleb gt Jisr-Ash-Shugur gtBadama gt Baksariya - Ein El-Bayda (Badama) - Hanbushiyeh - Kherbet Eljoz- Ramliyeh Idleb gt Jisr-Ash-Shugur gtJanudiyeh gtFoz - Zuf / Hamama - Kafr Debbin - Janudiyeh - Maland Idleb gt Jisr-Ash-Shugur gt Jisr-Ash-Shugur gt Eshtabraq - eyn albarda - Frikeh (Shat-ha) - Kafir (Jisr-Ash-Shugur) - Qaysiyeh - Watba
Each Rapid response team (RRT) will work in specific locations and will cover (pregnant and lactating women and children under 5) - 1 RRTs in Idleb gt Ariha - 9 RRts in Idleb gt Harim - 5 RRts in Idleb gt Jisr-Ash-Shugur
These Rapid response teams will work in parallel and in coordination with the available health facilities in the target areas. The RRTs will provide integrated health, nutrition, child protection, and hygiene promotion.
Nurses will screen the children under 5 and refer the ones with dangers signs and medical problems to the available health facilities.
Community Health Workers (CHWs) will assess and screen nutritional status among the children under 5 and distribute nutritional supplies to them where needed. Also, the infant and young child feeding practices in emergencies (IYCF-E) services will be provided to prevent any case of malnutrition by:
- Counseling the PLWs and caregivers of children under 24 months of age and providing messages on IYCF-E recommended practices to mothers who have malnourished children. - Distributing micronutrients and nutrition supplies for the PLWs and children. - Reporting to the cluster any distribution of breast milk substitute.
Midwives will screen pregnant and lactating women and refer the ones with any danger signs or medical problems to the nearest facilities.
Also, a pre and rapid coordination combined with referrals will be in place if the team notices or identifies any sign of abuse or violence among children under 5 and or mothers. All cases of violence against women and children will be referred to a pre-identified center.
This response will adopt the recommendation of the cluster in COVID-19 context to minimize the risk of infection for staff and beneficiaries through:
- Mercy-USA will apply recommended IPC measures at RRTs sites - IYCF-E counseling and messages could be conducted via WhatsApp
-Dissemination of information on COVID-19 signs, symptoms and IPC measures -All other needed measures will apply according to the cluster recommendation
Also, this project will involve empowering mothers and HH members through training to screen their own children for malnutrition by teaching them how to use color-coded Mid-Upper Arm Circumference (MUAC) tapes and check for Odema.

reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs
